title: State v. Coleman
description: In this case, the court determines double jeopardy does not prevent a new trial based on a subsequent indictment, following a mistrial granted on the defendants' motion, which was prompted by remarks made by the prosecuting attorney in his opening statement.
text:
State v. Coleman


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Appellant,
v.
Lawrence A. Coleman, Arthur Caesar, and Scott A. Adamson,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4008
Heard May 11, 2005 â€“ Filed July 5, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Chief, State Grand Jury Sherri A. Lydon, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Robert E. Bogan, all of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
Francis L. Bell, Jr., of Lancaster, Robert T. Williams, Sr., of Lexington and Robert William Mills, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  The State appeals the trial courtâ€™s order finding double jeopardy barred the State from prosecuting Lawrence A. Coleman, Arthur Caesar, and Scott A. Adamson.Â  We reverse.Â  
FACTS
On January 28, 2001, John Allen was working as a guard at the Kershaw Correctional Institution.Â  Another guard called for assistance with two inmates, Erving and Jones, who were causing a disturbance.Â  Allen, Caesar, and other guards responded and escorted Erving and Jones to the â€œspecial management unitâ€ located in an adjacent building.Â  As they were crossing the prison yard, Erving became aggressive toward Allen.Â  Allen sprayed Erving with mace and forced him to the ground.Â  While Allen had Erving on the ground, Jones jumped on Allen from behind and punched him on the back of his head and the side of his face.Â  
After the altercation ended, Coleman, the highest-ranking guard on duty, spoke to the guards who were involved about the incident.Â  Coleman ordered Jones handcuffed and escorted to the â€œAâ€ buildingâ€™s holding cell.Â  Caesar and Adamson escorted Jones to the holding cell, and Coleman joined them en route. Â Caesar left briefly and returned with Allen.Â  Coleman ordered Jonesâ€™s handcuffs removed, and Allen pushed Jones from behind.Â  Allen and Jones then exchanged blows with Allen hitting, kicking, and biting Jones while the other guards, including Respondents, watched without intervening.Â  After one of the guards made the comment to Jones that he had â€œbetter not win,â€ Jones curled into a ball on the floor and Allen continued to kick him.Â  
After Jones reported the incident, the State Law Enforcement Division (SLED) investigated.Â  Although Allen originally denied the altercation occurred, he later confessed and assisted SLED in its investigation.Â  The grand jury indicted Respondents on the common law charge of misconduct in office.Â  
At the initial trial, Respondents made several objections to portions of the solicitorâ€™s opening statement.Â  The following colloquy took place:

Solicitor Boganâ€™s Opening Statement:Â  As I mentioned to you, there are two incidents that occurred here.Â  The first one, the transfer from the Oak building holding cell to the Special Management Unit concerned a little scuffle that was handled fairly professionally by the officers, and then the second attitude adjustment if you will of inmate. . . 
Defense counsel Mr. Mills:Â  Your Honor, I object.Â  Heâ€™s getting into argument at this time.
The Court:Â  Iâ€™ll allow it.Â  Go ahead.
Mr. Bogan:Â  The second incident that occurred in the A building holding cell with inmate Jones and the six corrections officers.Â  How do you know that that took place dishonestly, corruptly?Â  The evidence will show in this case that the officers took the position that it never happened.
Defense counsel Mr. Bell:Â  Your Honor, Iâ€™m going to object to that comment unless heâ€™s going to point to one particular officer.Â  My officer never took that position.Â  Iâ€™m going to object.Â  Thatâ€™s unfair comment that heâ€™s not going to be able to prove as to my client.Â  I canâ€™t speak for anybody else.
The Court:Â  Well, of course, youâ€™ll be able to address that in your opening, Mr. Bell, but Mr. Bogan, if itâ€™s comments that apply to only one of the defendants, you should identify or exclude the ones that it doesnâ€™t apply to.
. . .
Mr. Bogan:Â  Ladies and Gentlemen, weâ€™ll present some testimony concerning what each of the defendants did, if anything, concerning the dishonesty and corruption that occurred in this case.Â  Consider this, no report, youâ€™ll hear testimony, was ever filed concerning - -
Mr. Bell:Â  Objection, Your Honor, I - - - the indictment charges me with what occurred on the 28th and nothing thereafter.Â  Iâ€™m going to object to the State trying to expand what he says I did wrong.Â  Itâ€™s not in the indictment, Your Honor.
Mr. Mills:Â  I join in - - -
Mr. Bell:Â  He cannot - - - He cannot convict me of something Iâ€™m not indicted in.
Defense counsel Mr. Williams:Â  I also join in that.
Mr. Bell:Â  Iâ€™m not indicted on that.
The Court:Â  Mr. Bogan?
Mr. Bogan:Â  Thank you, Your Honor.Â  I contend that the fact that no report was ever filed and that the fact that the report that was filed only contained half the story is evidence of the dishonesty and the cover-up.
Mr. Bell:Â  I move for a mistrial, Your Honor.
Mr. Mills:Â  I would join the motion, Your Honor.
Mr. Williams:Â  I would join.

Thereafter, the trial judge excused the jury and heard arguments regarding the motion for a mistrial.Â  Respondentsâ€™ attorneys argued the solicitorâ€™s comments, characterizing the guardsâ€™ failure to file a report as a cover-up, went beyond the scope of the indictment.Â  The solicitor opposed the motion for a mistrial, arguing the guardsâ€™ failure to file a report was evidence of dishonesty, an element of the crime charged.Â  Although the trial judge stated he knew the solicitorâ€™s comments were â€œnot an intentional thing,â€ he granted a mistrial.Â  
Respondentsâ€™ attorneys opposed beginning the trial anew the following day, so the case was rescheduled.Â  Before the case was called to trial for the second time, the solicitor obtained a superseding indictment containing language referencing the â€œcover-upâ€ to avoid another mistrial.Â  Subsequently, Respondentsâ€™ attorneys moved to dismiss the case based on double jeopardy.Â  After a hearing, the trial judge dismissed the case based on his finding that the solicitor â€œforced these Defendants into seeking a mistrial after jeopardy had attached.â€Â  The State appeals.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The State argues the trial judge erred in dismissing the case based on the Double Jeopardy Clauses of the United States and South Carolina Constitutions.Â  We agree. 
The Double Jeopardy Clauses of the United States and South Carolina Constitutions protect citizens from being twice placed in jeopardy of life or liberty.Â  See U.S. Const. amend. V (â€œNo person shall be . . . subject for the same offence to be twice put in jeopardy of life or limb. . . .â€); S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 12 (â€œNo person shall be subject for the same offense to be twice put in jeopardy of life or liberty . . . .â€).Â  Under the law of double jeopardy, a defendant may not be prosecuted for the same offense after an acquittal, a conviction, or an improvidently granted mistrial.Â  State v. Rowlands, 343 S.C. 454, 457, 539 S.E.2d 717, 718 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
In Oregon v. Kennedy, the Supreme Court adopted a rule providing that a defendant who has moved for and been granted a mistrial may successfully invoke the Double Jeopardy Clause to prevent a second prosecution only when the prosecutorâ€™s conduct giving rise to the mistrial was intended to â€œgoadâ€ or provoke him into moving for the mistrial.Â  456 U.S. 667, 676-77 (1982).Â  See also State v. Mathis, 359 S.C. 450, 460, 597 S.E.2d 872, 877 (Ct. App. 2004) (applying same standard in South Carolina).Â  
Under this standard, the determination of whether double jeopardy attaches depends upon whether the prosecutorial misconduct was undertaken with the specific intent â€œto subvert the protections afforded by the Double Jeopardy Clause.â€Â  Mathis, 359 S.C. at 460, 597 S.E.2d at 877 (quoting Kennedy, 456 U.S. at 676).Â  The trial courtâ€™s finding concerning the prosecutorâ€™s intent is a factual one and will not be disturbed on appeal unless clearly erroneous.Â  Id. at 460-61, 597 S.E.2d at 877-78. 
Here, there is clear error.Â  At the initial trial, the trial court specifically found the solicitorâ€™s comments did not intentionally provoke the Respondents into moving for a mistrial.Â  At the time of Respondentsâ€™ objection, after the jury was excused, the solicitor apologized to the court and stated he was, in good faith, trying to establish dishonesty, an element of the crime charged.Â  The trial judge concluded:

I know that it was not an intentional thing.Â  I donâ€™t mean to imply that at all, but I - - - you know, my job is to make certain that these gentlemen get a fair trial. . . . And Iâ€™m just not certain - - - well, one, I am certain that you didnâ€™t intentionally do anything to cause that not to happen, but Iâ€™m certain that thereâ€™s no way to give them a curative instruction that would erase - - - erase it from their mind, and for that reason, Iâ€™m going to grant a mistrial in this case. 

In the order of dismissal based on double jeopardy, the trial court considered this statement by the solicitor:Â  â€œI contend that the fact that no report was ever filed and the fact that the report that was filed only contained half the story as evidence of the dishonesty and cover-up.â€Â  The trial court concluded the solicitor forced Respondents to move for a mistrial â€œbecause it was the third time the Prosecutor had made this statement before the jury after twice being instructed not to. . . .â€Â  
However, the record conclusively shows the objections to the solicitorâ€™s first two comments were on other grounds.Â  The ground for the first objection was for exceeding the scope of the opening statement and â€œgetting into argument.â€Â  The second objection dealt with the solicitorâ€™s failure to differentiate between the three defendants.Â  We fail to see, based on the record, any intent by the solicitor to force a mistrial.Â  The trial court overruled the first objection.Â  The trial court essentially ruled again for the solicitor on the second objection, although the court also cautioned the solicitor to differentiate between the defendants.Â  The last objection, and the only one on the grounds giving rise to the double jeopardy issue, resulted in the motion for mistrial even before there was a ruling on the objection by the trial court.Â  
Based on the record, there is only one reasonable inference.Â  Under the facts of this case, the solicitorâ€™s conduct was unintentional as a matter of law.Â  Accordingly, we find that the Double Jeopardy Clause is no bar to Respondentsâ€™ retrial.Â  The order of the trial court is 
 REVERSED.
 ANDERSON and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: In the Matter of the Care and Treatment of John Phillip Corley
description: The court of appeals found Rule 52(a), SCRCP, requires findings of fact and conclusions of law in annual probable cause determination hearings required under South Carolinaâ€™s Sexually Violent Predator Act.  The court found the circuit court erred in failing to make such findings in the case at bar, but that the error was harmless because the record clearly documents a factual basis for concluding that probable cause was lacking.  The court further found a Constitutional challenge to the Act was unpreserved.
text:
In the Matter of Corley


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
In the Matter of the Care and Treatment of John Phillip Corley,
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4009
Submitted June 1, 2005 â€“Filed July 5, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Sonja R. Tate, and Michael N. Loebl, of Augusta, Georgia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General R. Westmoreland Clarkson, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  Following a determination, pursuant to the Sexually Violent Predator Act (the Act), that John Phillip Corley is a sexually violent predator, a probable cause hearing was held on the issue of whether the results of the statutory annual review warranted a trial to determine if Corley should be released from confinement.Â  Corley appeals from the circuit courtâ€™s finding that there was no probable cause to believe his mental abnormality or personality disorder had so changed that he was safe to be at large and that he was not likely to commit acts of sexual violence.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
In March 1993, a jury convicted Corley of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature and he was sentenced to ten years.Â  In August 1993, Corley pled guilty to criminal sexual conduct in the second degree and was sentenced to a concurrent term of fourteen years.Â  
A jury subsequently found Corley to be a sexually violent predator and he was committed pursuant to the Act.Â  The judgment was affirmed on appeal.Â  In the Matter of the Care & Treatment of Corley, 353 S.C. 202, 577 S.E.2d 451 (2003).Â  In May 2003, Corley petitioned the court for release from commitment pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-110 (Supp. 2002).[1]Â  
The circuit court held a probable cause hearing in September 2003 to determine whether the results of Corleyâ€™s annual review warranted a trial on the issue of his fitness for release.Â  Following the submission of written reports and arguments by counsel, the court found probable cause did not exist to believe Corleyâ€™s mental abnormality or personality disorder had so changed that he was safe to be at large and unlikely to commit acts of sexual violence.Â  Corley challenges the circuit courtâ€™s finding of no probable cause. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Sufficiency of the Order
Section 44-48-110 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2002)â€”which was applicable at the time of Corleyâ€™s September 2003 hearingâ€”set forth the procedure for reviewing commitments under the Act.Â  A person committed under the Act must have an annual examination of his mental conditions.Â  Id.Â  The court must conduct an annual hearing to review the committed personâ€™s status, and the committed person may petition the court for release at this hearing.Â  Id.Â  At the hearing, the circuit court uses a probable cause standard to determine whether sufficient evidence exists to go to trial:Â  

If the court determines that probable cause exists to believe that the personâ€™s mental abnormality or personality disorder has so changed that the person is safe to be at large and, if released, is not likely to commit acts of sexual violence, the court shall schedule a trial on the issue.Â  

Id.Â 
In this case, the circuit court conducted an annual review hearing and determined that probable cause did not exist to warrant a trial on Corelyâ€™s request for release from confinement.Â  The court considered the evidence and determined that the lack of the requisite probable cause precluded a further hearing or trial.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s conclusory order appears to be a form order submitted by the State.Â  Corley maintains that the circuit courtâ€™s order failed to make adequate findings of fact and conclusions of law to permit judicial review.
The first question before us, which we answer in the affirmative, is whether the circuit court must make detailed findings in connection with a probable cause determination in an annual review under the Act.Â  We find especially persuasive our supreme courtâ€™s sound analysis in In the Matter of the Treatment and Care of Luckabaugh, 351 S.C. 122, 568 S.E.2d 338 (2002).Â  The court held in Luckabaugh that the circuit court erred in failing to set forth its findingsâ€”and violating Rule 52(a), SCRCPâ€”in an initial merits hearing under the Act.[2]Â  Luckabaugh recognizes the obviousâ€”meaningful appellate review is more readily obtained when we are presented with a clear presentation of the basis for the circuit courtâ€™s findings:

Trial courts, sitting without juries in an action at law, write their findings specially and separately: 
  
to allow a reviewing court to determine from the record whether the judgmentâ€”and the legal conclusions which underlie itâ€”represent a correct application of the law.Â  The requirement for appropriately detailed findings is thus not a mere formality or a rule of empty ritual;Â  it is designed instead to dispose of the issues raised by the pleadings and to allow the appellate courts to perform their proper function in the judicial system. 
  

Id. at 132, 568 S.E.2d at 343 (internal citations omitted) (quoting Coble v. Coble, 268 S.E.2d 185, 189 (N.C. 1980)). 
There are, to be sure, innumerable instances where the strictures of Rule 52(a) do not apply.Â  Trial courts routinely make rulings in a variety of settings (preliminary to, and in the context of a, trial) without the need to issue a formal order containing specific findings of fact.Â  â€œWe do not require a lower court to set out findings on all the myriad factual questions arising in a particular case.â€Â  Luckabaugh, 351 S.C. at 133, 568 S.E.2d at 343.Â  We are not presented here with a mere evidentiary ruling or some peripheral determination.Â  An annual review hearing under the Act is in the nature of a trial.Â  A finding of â€œno probable causeâ€ is indeed dispositive of the proceeding and provides the finding from which an appeal is taken.[3]
Â We hold that, in making a probable cause determination in an annual review under the Act, the circuit court should substantially comply with Rule 52(a) and â€œfind the facts specially and state separately its conclusions of law.â€ 
We do not find, however, that the deficient order requires reversal.Â  Unlike the uncertainty that surrounded the circuit courtâ€™s determination in Luckabaugh, a review of this record clearly documents a factual basis for concluding that probable cause was lacking.Â  From the comments of and questions posed by the able circuit judge, we need not speculate as to the basis of his decision, for we clearly discernâ€”as discussed belowâ€”the basis of his finding of no probable cause. 
II.Â  Probable Cause Finding
Concerning Corleyâ€™s challenge to the circuit courtâ€™s probable cause finding, such ruling will not be disturbed â€œunless found to be without evidence that reasonably supports the hearing courtâ€™s finding.â€Â  In the Matter of the Care & Treatment of Tucker, 353 S.C. 466, 470, 578 S.E.2d 719, 721 (2003).Â  
Evidence reasonably supports the circuit courtâ€™s probable cause finding.Â  Although Corley made progress, his behavior remained â€œa big problem.â€Â  He received at least five major disciplinary citations in the year prior to the review, some of which involved his â€œmanipulating to use the telephoneâ€ to make sexually inappropriate calls.Â  Corley had been involved in a sexual relationship with a staff member, and had threatened staff.Â  Additionally, he had numerous unexcused absences from group sessions.Â  Corley had not completed treatment.Â Â  At the time of the hearing, he was on the lowest level in the Treatment Incentive Program due to his inappropriate behavior on the unit.Â  
Dr. Lanette Atkins testified Corley needs further treatment.Â  Dr. Atkins further testified that based on Corleyâ€™s history of assaultive behavior and continuing manipulative behavior, he continues to be a risk to the community.Â  
In response, Corley offered the testimony of Carl Harry Douglas, a counselor who treats sex offenders in an outpatient setting.Â  Douglas testified Corley would need to continue in outpatient treatment if he were released.Â  However, the Act contains no provision for court-ordered outpatient treatment.Â  
We find ample support to sustain the circuit courtâ€™s finding of no probable cause.Â Â  
III.Â  Constitutional Challenge to the Act
Corley further requests a ruling that the Act is invalid on due process grounds.Â  This argument has not been preserved for appeal.Â  
Constitutional issues, like most others, must be raised to and ruled on by the trial court to be preserved for appeal.Â  See State v. Varvil, 338 S.C. 335, 339, 526 S.E.2d 248, 250 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The record contains no indication that Corley ever raised a due process argument in the circuit court.Â  This argument is not preserved for review.Â  
CONCLUSION
We find that the circuit courtâ€™s probable cause determination is supported by the evidence.Â  
 AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY, and HUFF, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Act was amended in 2004.Â  â€œThe 2004 amendment substituted â€˜mustâ€™ for â€˜shallâ€™ throughout and added [a] sentence relating to notification of the victim.â€Â  See Effect of Amendment, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-44-110 (Supp. 2004).Â  This appeal is unaffected by the 2004 amendment. 
[2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Rule 52(a) provides as follows:Â  â€œIn all actions tried upon the facts without a jury . . . , the court shall find the facts specially and state separately its conclusions of law thereon, and judgment shall be entered pursuant to Rule 58 (providing for entry of judgment) . . . .â€Â  Rule 52(a), SCRCP.
[3] Â Â Â Â Â Â  In the family court context, Rule 26(a), SCFCR, provides a counterpart to Rule 52(a), SCRCP.Â  When considering family court orders deemed conclusory, and thus incapable of proper judicial review, this court noted in Atkinson v. Atkinson, 279 S.C. 454, 456, 309 S.E.2d 14, 15 (Ct. App. 1983):Â  
Proper appellate review is extremely difficult, if not impossible, where a lower court order omits specific findings of fact to support its legal conclusions. We appreciate the problems that Family Court Judges may have from time to time in meeting the requirements of [Rule 26(a)]. Unremitting workloads and arduous responsibilities hamstring even the most dedicated. Nonetheless, we believe that strict compliance with the rule promotes the administration of justice at every judicial level.
We echo the sentiments of the court in Atkinson, and recognize that a trial courtâ€™s specific findings of fact and conclusions of law are critical to meaningful appellate review.Â  We do not intend to unnecessarily increase our trial courtsâ€™ substantial existing burdens, but instead our goal is to seek greater efficiency in the â€œadministration of justiceâ€ by facilitating proper appellate review.

title: Matthews v. Dennis
description: The Dennises appeal an order finding that their property was subject to an easement.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ruby E. Matthews, Bobby J. Matthews and David McCoy,
Respondents,
v.
Gloria Dennis and Alton Dennis, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Kevin M. Barth, Special Referee

Opinion No. 4010
Submitted May 1, 2005 â€“ Filed July 5, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Gordon B. Jenkinson, of Kingstree, for Appellants.
S. Porter Stewart, II, of Florence, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Gloria and Alton Dennis (â€œDefendantsâ€) appeal the special refereeâ€™s determination that their property was subject to an easement in favor of adjoining property owned by Ruby E. Matthews, Bobby J. Matthews, and David McCoy (collectively referred to as â€œPlaintiffsâ€).Â  Specifically, the special referee found Plaintiffs established their right to an easement under the theories of prescription and necessity.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Gloria Dennis and Ruby Matthews are first cousins.Â  In 1946, Otis McKnight, who was Gloriaâ€™s father and Rubyâ€™s uncle, built a home place on a tract of land that he owned in Florence County, South Carolina.Â  This property, consisting of about twenty-one and one-half acres of farmland, was adjacent to a tract of land owned by Otisâ€™s brother.Â  
In 1951, Otis received from his brother a thirty-foot-wide strip of land, running approximately one-quarter of a mile between their respective properties.Â  According to the deed of conveyance, the property, commonly known as â€œHawk Lane,â€ was â€œto be used as a roadbed leading from Anderson Bridge road to [the] home of Otis McKnight.â€Â  The deed also noted that G.M. Evans, Rubyâ€™s father, helped to stake out the property and that Bobby Matthews, Sr., Rubyâ€™s now deceased husband, was present when this took place.Â  Other than Hawk Lane, there is no documented legal access to Otisâ€™s property, and the location of the roadway has not changed since the time that Otis acquired it.Â  
In 1963, Otis conveyed a one-acre portion of his land to Defendants, who have lived on this property since 1964. In 1969, Otis transferred his remaining property to Bobby Matthews, Sr., while reserving a life estate for himself and his wife in the one acre of land where their home was located.Â  Upon Otisâ€™s death in 1976, his remaining property transferred to his widow and children.Â  By deed dated April 23, 1986, Otisâ€™s heirs transferred their interest in Hawk Lane to Defendants.Â  
In 1970, Bobby Matthews, Sr., transferred a portion of the property that he received from McKnight to other individuals.Â  Two roads, Vansel and Farmer Roads, border the property.Â  The testimony differed in regards to whether the roads were in existence at the time of the 1970 transfer.Â  In 1984, Bobby Matthews, Sr., transferred the remainder of his property to Ruby.Â  In 1998, Ruby transferred a one-acre parcel to her nephew, David McCoy.Â  In 2002, she transferred her remaining property to her son, Bobby J. Matthews, while reserving a life estate for herself.
Plaintiffsâ€™ property is presently bounded by land owned by the McAllister family.Â  A roadbed known as McAllister Lane traverses the McAllister property and is within a quarter-mile from Rubyâ€™s home.
The Matthews have rented the McAllister property for farming.Â  With permission from the McAllisters, they have periodically used McAllister Lane for access to and from their property; however, Hawk Lane has always been the main access route.
A dispute over the use of Hawk Lane resulted in an attempt by Defendants to block Plaintiffsâ€™ access to the road in July 2000.Â  This prompted Plaintiffs to bring the instant action to have an easement declared over Hawk Lane for access to their property.Â  In their complaint, they alleged they had an easement by prescription, necessity, or dedication.Â  Defendants denied Plaintiffsâ€™ right to an easement and sought an injunction prohibiting their use of Hawk Lane.
The case was transferred to a special referee, who found (1) Plaintiffs had both a prescriptive easement and an easement by necessity to use Hawk Lane to access their property, but (2) Plaintiffs failed to prove Hawk Lane had been dedicated to public use.Â  Following the denial of their motion for reconsideration, Defendants appealed.[2]Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Citing the Maine case of Rollins v. Blackden,[3] Defendants first assert the 1986 conveyance of Hawk Lane to them by the heirs of Otis McKnight â€œinterruptedâ€ the use of the property and, therefore, the time for calculating the twenty years necessary for a prescriptive easement should have started in 1986.Â  They also contend the twenty-year prescriptive period could not begin to run against them until they acquired title to the property in 1986 because they could not have sued to enjoin the use of a road that they did not own.Â  To the extent these arguments have been preserved for appeal, we find they are without merit.[4]
Creation of a prescriptive easement requires the following:Â  â€œ(1) There must be [a] continued and uninterrupted use or enjoyment of the right for a period of 20 years.Â  (2) The identity of the thing enjoyed must be proven.Â  (3) The use must have been adverse or under a claim of right.â€[5]Â  â€œPeriods of prescriptive use may be tacked together to make up the prescriptive period if there is a transfer between the prescriptive users of either the inchoate servitude or the estate benefited by the inchoate servitude.â€[6]Â  
In the present case, Plaintiffs have used Hawk Lane continuously, openly, and without interruption since at least 1969 for ingress and egress to their property.Â  As late as 1998, the Florence Municipal/County Planning Department approved a plat that was prepared for David McCoy for the installation of a well and septic system on the Matthews property and depicted Hawk Lane as the only access to the property.Â  Hawk Lane has been identified by Florence County with a standard blue road sign, and, as testified by Alton Dennis, is part of the emergency 9-1-1 system.Â  It also appears the twenty-year prescriptive period ran long before Defendantsâ€™ initial attempt to barricade Hawk Lane, which, according to Ruby, was about eight years before the final hearing in this case.[7]Â  Under these circumstances, we hold the evidence in the record supports the special refereeâ€™s finding that Plaintiffs successfully established uninterrupted use of Hawk Lane for at least twenty years.[8]Â  The fact that Hawk Lane was conveyed to Defendants during the prescriptive period did not interrupt Plaintiffsâ€™ use of the roadway. [9] 
2.Â  We disagree with Defendantsâ€™ argument that Plaintiffsâ€™ claim of right was insufficient because it was based on a mistaken belief of ownership. 
A party claiming a prescriptive easement under a claim of right must â€œdemonstrate a substantial belief that he had the right to use the parcel or road based upon the totality of circumstances surrounding his use.â€[10]
We hold the record supports the special refereeâ€™s finding that â€œPlaintiffs have established that theirs has always been a belief that they have had a right to use of the subject roadway for ingress and egress, and had openly done so for well in excess of twenty years.â€Â  Ruby testified that members of her family had always used Hawk Lane for access while acknowledging they may not have had legal documents granting them the right to do this.Â  Moreover, this case is distinguishable from Babb v. Harrison,[11] which Defendants cite in support of their position.Â  Whereas the party asserting the easement in Babb based her initial claim on one of ownership of the property over which she asserted a right of use, the testimony in the present case reflects that Plaintiffs believed that they had only the right to use Hawk Lane; there is no suggestion that they ever believed they owned Hawk Lane itself. [12] Â  
3.Â  Finally, Defendants argue Plaintiffsâ€™ use of the road should be deemed permissive because of the family relationship between the parties.Â  We disagree.
 Lynch v. Lynch,[13] which Defendants cite in support of their position, is distinguishable from the present case.Â  Lynch concerned a claim of adverse possession and not a claim for a prescriptive easement.Â  Moreover, that decision addresses only immediate family relationships, such as between siblings or parent and child, rather than extended kinship, such as in the present case.Â  In any event, based on case law from both South Carolina and other jurisdictions, we see no reason to hold that the degree of affinity between the parties in this case is by itself sufficient reason to reverse the special refereeâ€™s finding that Plaintiffs met their burden of proof in establishing their right to a prescriptive easement. [14] 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  We address only those arguments challenging the special refereeâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law regarding an easement by prescription.Â  Because we affirm the determination that Plaintiffs had established their right to an easement under this theory, we make no ruling on their entitlement to an easement by necessity. Â See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling an appellate court need not review remaining issues when its determination of a prior issue is dispositive of the appeal); Dwyer v. Tom Jenkins Realty, 289 S.C. 118, 120, 344 S.E.2d 886, 888 (Ct. title: State v. Nicholson
description: The defendant appeals his convictions on three counts of second-degree criminal sexual conduct.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
William Max Nicholson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
Â Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4011
Heard June 7, 2005 â€“ Filed July 5, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Larry C. Brandt, of Walhalla, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Christina T. Adams, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  William Max Nicholson appeals his convictions for three counts of second-degree criminal sexual conduct.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The trial in this case revolved around the accusations of a young adult male who was born March 25, 1980.Â  In late 2001, he told his mother that Nicholson sexually assaulted him several years earlier.Â  
On December 21, 2001, the accuser gave a written statement about the alleged assaults to the Oconee County Sheriffâ€™s Department.Â  According to the statement, the accuser first met Nicholson, a high school science teacher, when he was a ninth-grade student in Nicholsonâ€™s physical science class at West Oak High School.Â  The accuser participated in tasks such as setting up labs and cleaning up chemical spills.Â  Eventually, he began to receive small sums of money from Nicholson for this work.Â  At that time, the accuser was not approached in a sexual manner.Â  
After the school year ended, the accuser, at Nicholsonâ€™s request, began doing odd jobs around Nicholsonâ€™s house and receiving payment from Nicholson for his services.Â  Although the accuser could not remember exactly how Nicholson approached him, he related that the â€œincidentsâ€ began only after â€œa few times of doing the workâ€ and that they were â€œin the nature of oral sexâ€ performed by Nicholson on him.Â  
The following school year, the accuser was initially enrolled at Walhalla High School, but later transferred back to West Oak High School.Â  After he transferred back to West Oak, he visited Nicholsonâ€™s classroom frequently even though he did not have Nicholson for class.Â  During the summer, the accuser helped Nicholson move to another residence.Â  Although the move was completed before the end of the summer, Nicholson offered the accuser additional work, promising the pay would be fair and a bonus was possible.Â  Throughout the completion of those tasks, the oral sex continued, probably at least every other day, for the duration of the summer.Â  When the accuser reached eleventh grade, he continued his relationship with Nicholson and claimed that he received at least a thousand dollars per month for his companionship.Â  The incidents became less frequent when the accuser reached twelfth grade, and he surmised this was because he was approaching adulthood and Nicholsonâ€™s â€œfascination was strictly adolescent males.â€Â  Even so, the accuser claimed that he visited Nicholson at various times in the month preceding the investigation and that Nicholson paid him a total of about one thousand dollars during that time. 
As part of the investigation, law enforcement officers outfitted the accuser with a recording device and sent him to Nicholsonâ€™s home on two occasions for the express purpose of eliciting incriminating statements from Nicholson.Â  They also videotaped Nicholsonâ€™s home while Nicholson and his accuser were inside talking and filmed the accuser on the porch talking with Nicholson as the accuser was preparing to leave the premises.Â  Although Nicholson made no direct admissions on the tape, he did not refute statements by the accuser.
Authorities arrested Nicholson on January 2, 2002.Â  After a preliminary hearing on February 22, 2002, and February 26, 2002, the Oconee County Grand Jury issued three indictments against Nicholson for second-degree criminal sexual conduct, charging him with committing acts of fellatio on his accuser during the periods of June 1 through June 30, 1995; July 1 through July 31, 1995; and August 1 through August 18, 1995.Â  
After a jury trial commencing October 21, 2002, Nicholson was convicted on all three indictments and sentenced to twelve years.Â  After the trial judge denied his post-trial motions, Nicholson filed this appeal.
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Nicholson argues the trial judge should have dismissed the indictments because the time periods alleged were not sufficiently specific.Â  In particular, he complains that without more specific dates in the indictments, he could not avail himself of the defense of alibi and other testimony that could have refuted his accuserâ€™s claims or impeached his accuserâ€™s credibility.Â  We reject these arguments.
â€œWhere time is not an essential element of the offense, the indictment need not specifically charge the precise time the offense allegedly occurred.â€[1]Â  â€œ[T]he sufficiency of an indictment must be judged from a practical standpoint, with all of the circumstances of the particular case in mind.â€[2]Â  
In this case, time was not an essential element of the charged offenses.[3]Â  Moreover, although Nicholson argued in his brief that the trial judge should have, in the alternative, required the State to make the dates of the offenses more definite and certain, we do not see any indication in the record that this issue was clearly raised at trial.[4]
2.Â  We disagree with Nicholsonâ€™s argument that the trial judge erred in denying his directed verdict motion.
Under Rule 19(a) of the South Carolina Rules of Criminal Procedure, â€œthe court shall direct a verdict in the defendantâ€™s favor on any offense charged in the indictment after the evidence on either side is closed, if there is a failure of competent evidence tending to prove the charge in the indictment.â€[5]Â  In considering a directed verdict motion, the court â€œshall consider only the existence or non-existence of the evidence and not its weight.â€[6]Â  â€œIf there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, an appellate court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.â€[7]Â  
At the close of the testimony, Nicholson moved for a directed verdict on the ground that there was â€œno credible evidence as to all the elements upon which the burden of proof lies upon the State.â€Â  On appeal, he alleges there were inconsistencies and time gaps in the accuserâ€™s testimony and suggests, among other things, that the evidence supported a finding that the alleged abuse occurred after the accuserâ€™s sixteenth birthday and was therefore outside the statutory age limit for the offense with which he was charged.[8]Â  We agree with the trial judge, however, that, viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the State, Nicholson was not entitled to a directed verdict.
The accuser testified Nicholson performed oral sex on him â€œthroughout the summerâ€ of 1995.Â  Specifically, he averred the oral sex happened in June, July, and August of 1995, and at a frequency of two to three times per week.Â  There was no dispute that the accuserâ€™s date of birth was March 25, 1980, which would have made him under the age of sixteen during the summer of 1995.Â  It further appears uncontested that he was younger than Nicholson and had been a student in Nicholsonâ€™s class, which would have placed Nicholson in a â€œposition of familial, custodial, or official authority to coerce the victim to submit.â€[9]Â  Any concerns about contradictory statements by the accuser, whether on the stand or outside the courtroom setting, were ultimately about his credibility and therefore in the domain of the jury.[10]
3.Â  Nicholson also contends he was deprived of a fair trial because the presiding trial judge instructed the solicitor on how to introduce a piece of evidence against him.Â  We disagree.
During the trial, the solicitor sought to introduce into evidence a composite audiotape recording of conversations between Nicholson and his accuser that took place on December 20 and 27, 2001.Â  While the solicitor was attempting to lay a foundation for admission of the recording, the trial judge, apparently dissatisfied with the solicitorâ€™s line of questioning, undertook to advise her outside the presence of the jury about the particulars that he viewed as necessary steps in this procedure.Â  Nicholson objected to the â€œdepth and detailâ€ of the assistance to the State.Â  After a recess, the solicitor, following the trial judgeâ€™s advice, made a successful proffer of the tape.
We find no error in the trial judgeâ€™s intervention in this case.Â  In State v. Gaskins, the supreme court, quoting State v. Anderson, reiterated the following â€œduties and limitationsâ€ that a trial judge must observe while conducting a trial:

A grave responsibility rests upon a trial judge.Â  It is his duty to see to it that justice be done in every case, if it can be done according to law; and, if he thinks that the attorney for either party, either from inadvertence or any other cause, has failed to ask the witnesses the questions necessary and proper to bring out all the testimony which tends to ascertain the truth of the matter under investigation, we can see no legal objection to his propounding such questions; but, of course, he should do so in a fair and impartial manner, and should not by the form or manner of his questions express or indicate to the jury his opinion as to the facts of the case, or as to the weight or sufficiency of the evidence.[11]

In our view, the trial judge did not exceed the limits recognized in Gaskins.Â  The jury was absent from the courtroom when the exchange at issue took place and thus could not have been affected by the trial judgeâ€™s remarks.Â  Moreover, the trial judge, when explaining to counsel what he required to lay a foundation, did not show any favoritism or otherwise indicate he had an opinion about the case.Â  We therefore hold that, contrary to Nicholsonâ€™s argument, the instructions did not result in the trial judgeâ€™s assumption of an adversarial role in the case.[12]
4.Â  Nicholson next argues the trial judge erred in refusing to strike a juror for cause.Â  We disagree.
In the voir dire, the trial judge asked if any members of the jury panel or their close personal friends or family members had been victims or claimed to be victims of any type of sexual offense or child abuse.Â  Among those answering the question in the affirmative was Juror Number 98, who advised the trial judge that his sister-in-law had been raped and the perpetrators â€œgot away with itâ€ and â€œ[i]t was pretty ugly.â€Â  Notwithstanding this information, Juror Number 98 was not dismissed for cause.Â  Nicholson argues on appeal that, during jury selection, he was forced to use one of his peremptory challenges to excuse this particular juror, which ultimately resulted in the seating of another juror whom he maintains he would have excused but for the exhaustion of all his peremptory strikes.Â  
Nicholsonâ€™s argument before the trial judge and on appeal focuses on the jurorâ€™s apparently â€œdeeply troubledâ€ demeanor and answer to a follow-up question from the trial judge that suggested that he could not be fair and impartial.Â  In the colloquy, it is evident that, when initially examining the juror, the trial judge asked two questions in immediate succession.Â  Whereas the first question called for a negative response from a qualified juror, the second question called for an affirmative answer.Â  To clear up the confusion, the trial judge impressed upon the juror the importance of a fair trial for both sides, inquiring of him, â€œCould you do that?â€ The juror responded affirmatively.Â  The trial judge also rephrased the other question, asking the juror, â€œAnd it would not interfere with your ability to be fair to the State and the defendant?â€ To this question the juror replied, â€œI donâ€™t think so.â€Â  Based on these exchanges, we hold the trial judge conducted an adequate examination into the jurorâ€™s impartiality and acted within his discretion in qualifying Juror Number 98.[13]
5.Â  During closing argument, the solicitor referred to Nicholsonâ€™s counsel as an â€œexperienced defense attorney,â€ which, Nicholson contends, may have suggested to the jury he was guilty because he hired experienced counsel.Â  The solicitor also made references about â€œjustice for allâ€ and advised the jurors that, in reaching a verdict, they could consider the trauma of the trial on Nicholsonâ€™s accuser.Â  Nicholson asserts the trial judge erred in denying his motion for a mistrial based on these allegedly improper comments.Â  We find no abuse of discretion.[14]Â  Nicholson failed to make a contemporaneous objection to either remark,[15] and, although the trial judge declined to declare a mistrial, he issued a curative instruction.[16]
6.Â  We reject Nicholsonâ€™s argument that the trial judge erred in refusing to grant his motion to suppress the testimony of an expert witness offered by the State or, in the alternative, to grant a continuance so he could obtain his own expert on the subject.Â  The witness was called to testify about the general characteristics of a sex abuse victim.Â  Nicholson contends the notice he received from the State about this witness was too close in time to the trial for him to prepare his defense.Â  The State, however, is not required to provide its witness list to a criminal defendant,[17] and the disclosure in the present case of this witness to the defense before trial was nothing more than a professional courtesy.Â  We therefore hold that the trial judge properly declined to suppress the expert testimony and acted within his discretion in refusing to continue the case.[18]
7.Â  Next, Nicholson asserts the trial judge should have required the State to release records concerning two psychological evaluations that had been performed on his accuser during a family court proceeding between the accuserâ€™s parents.Â  Nicholson further alleges the trial judge erred in limiting cross-examination of the accuser about his mental health history and in denying the defense â€œsufficient time and opportunity to effectively process certain information.â€Â  We find no error.
The records that Nicholson sought were not in the Stateâ€™s possession; and the trial judge did not allow full access of the documents to either the State or to the defense.Â  After receiving the records under seal and reviewing them for admissibility, the trial judge â€œdeclined to admit it based on the confidential nature of the reportâ€ and further noted that any probative value in the records would be outweighed by the fact that they were â€œremoteâ€ and â€œsomewhat cumulative.â€Â  We hold the trial judge followed the correct procedure in determining whether Nicholson could have access to his accuserâ€™s psychological evaluations and whether the evaluations were admissible.[19]Â  Moreover, we have reviewed the records, which were submitted to this court under seal, and concur with the trial judge that the evaluations were so remote in time they would render questionable any probative information they might yield in the present case.
8.Â  Nicholson asserts recordings by law enforcement of the conversations between him and his accuser should have been suppressed because they amounted to a denial of his right to counsel, an invasion of his privacy, and an unreasonable search and seizure.Â  We disagree.Â  When the tapes were made, Nicholson was not in police custody and had not been indicted.[20]Â  In addition, there was no dispute that the accuser in this case consented to have his conversations with Nicholson recorded.[21]
9.Â  Finally, Nicholson contends the cumulative effect of the errors he has alleged warrants a new trial.[22]Â  Because, however, we have determined that the trial judge did not err in any of the particulars alleged in this appeal, we likewise hold the cumulative error doctrine is inapplicable.
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Seabrook Island Property Ownersâ€™ Association, Respondent,
v.
Joseph A. Berger, Appellant.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 4012
Heard June 17, 2005 â€“ Filed July 5, 2005

Appeal From Charleston County
 Mikell R. Scarborough, Master-in-Equity


  
    
      
Paul A. James, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
David B. Wheeler and Edward T. Fenno, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Joseph A. Berger appeals the trial courtâ€™s order assessing attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of $39,194.08 in favor of Seabrook Island Property Ownersâ€™ Association (Seabrook).Â  Berger argues the award is excessive and the trial court abused its discretion by refusing to allow him to testify in person at trial.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
This case arises out of a dispute between Berger, who is a resident of Seabrook Island, and Seabrook.Â  The dispute began in 1997 when Seabrook notified Berger that his floating dock and unkempt yard violated Seabrookâ€™s covenants.Â  Seabrook alerted Berger to the violations on numerous occasions and informed him of assessments he was incurring for failing to remedy the problems.Â  After Berger neglected to correct the violations, Seabrook referred the matter to its attorney, David Wheeler, for enforcement and collection. 
Over the course of the next couple of years, Wheeler and his associates sent many letters to Berger and his attorneys.Â  Wheeler followed up with numerous attempts to resolve the matter.Â  After these attempts failed, Seabrook filed suit against Berger seeking injunctive relief and recovery of assessments levied for violations of the covenants.Â  The case was tried before Judge Roger M. Young who granted Seabrook injunctive relief, $43,945, and attorneyâ€™s fees and costs in an amount to be determined.Â  
Berger appealed Judge Youngâ€™s order.Â  The attorneyâ€™s fees determination was stayed pending the outcome of the appeal.Â  We affirmed Judge Youngâ€™s order in an unpublished opinion. Â Seabrook Prop. Owners Assâ€™n v. Berger, Op. No. 2003-UP-417 (Ct. App. filed June 19, 2003).Â  
On December 10, 2003, Seabrook petitioned the trial court to render an award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs, and included itemized invoices detailing the costs it incurred.Â  Thereafter, Berger requested a hearing, and the matter was set for February 23, 2004 before Judge Mikell R. Scarborough.Â  At the hearing, Bergerâ€™s attorney requested that Berger be permitted to testify to contest specific items in the bills.Â  The judge declined the request due to time considerations, but allowed Berger to submit a post-hearing affidavit setting forth his testimony.Â  The trial judge further requested that Berger provide information about his own attorneyâ€™s fees and asked him to outline why he thought Seabrookâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees were excessive.Â  
After reviewing Bergerâ€™s affidavit, the trial judge ruled that Seabrook had established the reasonableness of its attorneyâ€™s fees and awarded Seabrook attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of $39,194.08.Â  Berger filed a motion to vacate, alter, or amend the judgment and requested an opportunity to testify in person.Â  The trial judge denied the motion.Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Reasonableness of Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Berger argues the trial courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees should be vacated or reduced because it was excessive and punitive in nature.Â  We disagree.Â  
The general rule is that attorneyâ€™s fees are not recoverable unless authorized by contract or statute.Â  Blumberg v. Nealco, Inc.,  310 S.C. 492, 493, 427 S.E.2d 659, 660 (1993) (citing Baron Data Sys., Inc. v. Loter, 297 S.C. 382, 377 S.E.2d 296 (1989); Hegler v. Gulf Ins. Co., 270 S.C. 548, 243 S.E.2d 443 (1978); Collins v. Collins, 239 S.C. 170, 122 S.E.2d 1 (1961)).Â  â€œIn South Carolina, the authority to award attorneyâ€™s fees can come only from a statute or be provided for in the language of a contract.Â  There is no common law right to recover attorneyâ€™s fees.â€Â  Harris-Jenkins v. Nissan Car Mart, Inc., 348 S.C. 171, 176, 557 S.E.2d 708, 710 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 486 S.E.2d 750 (1997); American Fed. Bank, FSB v. Number One Main Joint Venture, 321 S.C. 169, 467 S.E.2d 439 (1996); Blumberg v. Nealco, Inc., 310 S.C. 492, 427 S.E.2d 659 (1993); Baron Data Sys., Inc. v. Loter, 297 S.C. 382, 377 S.E.2d 296 (1989); Dowaliby v. Chambless, 344 S.C. 558, 544 S.E.2d 646 (Ct. App. 2001); Harvey v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, 338 S.C. 500, 527 S.E.2d 765 (Ct. App. 2000); Global Protection Corp. v. Halbersberg, 332 S.C. 149, 503 S.E.2d 483 (Ct. App. 1998); Prevatte v. Asbury Arms, 302 S.C. 413, 396 S.E.2d 642 (Ct. App. 1990)).
â€œRestrictive covenants are contractual in nature.â€Â  Hoffman v. Cohen, 262 S.C. 71, 75, 202 S.E.2d 363, 365 (1974); see also Seabrook Island Property Owners Assâ€™n v. Pelzer, 292 S.C. 343, 347, 356 S.E.2d 411, 414 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œRestrictive covenants are contractual in nature and bind the parties thereto in the same manner as any other contract.â€) (citation omitted).Â  
The trial judgeâ€™s order analyzes Seabrookâ€™s contractual basis for recovery of attorneyâ€™s fees as follows:

Section 2 of The Protective Covenants for the Seabrook Island Development, as amended (the â€œCovenantsâ€), binds all property owners in the Development to the obligations set forth in the Covenants and derivative regulations; Paragraph 2(e) addresses the adoption, distribution, and enforcement of the regulations for the common good, including regulations for the design and construction of improvements on and for the maintenance of property, as well as sanctions for violations.Â  Section 3 of the Covenants provides that the Board of Directors of the SIPOA has the right to bill for fees, charges, costs and assessments contemplated by the Covenants and/or imposed pursuant to the SIPOAâ€™s Bylaws, as amended from time to time, and to institute legal proceedings to collect such sums, â€œincluding the right to charge and collect all necessary attorneysâ€™ fees, court costs and other collection expenses.â€Â  Section 7.3 of the Bylaws of the SIPOA, as amended, provides for Plaintiff to recover its attorneysâ€™ fees and costs incurred in actions to collect amounts due and owing.Â  Section 8.5 of the Bylaws provides that in any action to enforce the covenants, the Bylaws or rules and regulations of the SIPOA, â€œthe Property Owner, tenant, guest, invitee or other person responsible for the violation of which abatement is sought shall pay all costs, including reasonable attorneysâ€™ fees actually incurred.â€

We are, accordingly, dealing with a contract-based attorneyâ€™s fee award.
â€œWhere there is a contract, the award of attorneyâ€™s fees is left to the discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed unless an abuse of discretion is shown.â€Â  Baron Data Sys., Inc. v. Loter, 297 S.C. 382, 384, 377 S.E.2d 296, 297 (1989) (citing Smith v. Smith, 264 S.C. 624, 216 S.E.2d 541 (1975); Nelson v. Merritt, 281 S.C. 126, 314 S.E.2d 840 (Ct. App. 1984)); accord Blumberg, 310 S.C. at 493, 427 S.E.2d at 660.Â  â€œWhere an attorneyâ€™s services and their value are determined by the trier of fact, an appeal will not prevail if the findings of fact are supported by any competent evidence.â€Â  Baron Data Sys., 297 S.C. at 384, 377 S.E.2d at 297 (citing Singleton v. Collins, 251 S.C. 208, 161 S.E.2d 246 (1968)).
There are six factors to consider in determining an award of attorneyâ€™s fees: 1) nature, extent, and difficulty of the legal services rendered; 2) time and labor devoted to the case; 3) professional standing of counsel; 4) contingency of compensation; 5) fee customarily charged in the locality for similar services; and 6) beneficial results obtained. Blumberg, 310 S.C. at 494, 427 S.E.2d at 660 (citing Collins v. Collins, 239 S.C. 170, 122 S.E.2d 1 (1961)); Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 308, 486 S.E.2d 750, 760 (1997); Burton v. York County Sheriffâ€™s Dept., 358 S.C. 339, 358, 594 S.E.2d 888, 898 (Ct. App. 2004); Weatherford v. Price, 340 S.C. 572, 580, 532 S.E.2d 310, 314 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  On appeal an award of attorneyâ€™s fees will be affirmed so long as sufficient evidence in the record supports each factor.Â  Blumberg, 310 S.C. at 494, 427 S.E.2d at 660.
In the case sub judice, the trial judge made detailed findings of fact and considered the six factors enumerated in Blumberg in concluding the attorneyâ€™s fees were reasonable and customary.Â  The judge noted the case took more than six years to resolve, included an appeal, and constituted 250 hours of attorney time.Â  The rates outlined in the itemized billing records reflected Wheelerâ€™s normal rates for similar litigation, were customary for the community, and showed Wheeler made numerous attempts to resolve the matter short of trial.Â  Additionally, Wheeler is a respected practitioner in the area of homeownersâ€™ association law and achieved a beneficial result in this case.Â Â  
Bergerâ€™s arguments that he spent less money than Seabrook on attorneyâ€™s fees and that the case was â€œnot complicatedâ€ enough to warrant the award do not persuade us that the trial judge abused his discretion.Â  Berger represented himself at various stages in the dispute.Â  The judge found the issues presented were â€œcomplexâ€ and cited Judge Youngâ€™s order noting the â€œlengthy litigation process.â€Â  Based upon the trial courtâ€™s written findings and our review of the record, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in determining the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
Additionally, Bergerâ€™s argument the award of attorneyâ€™s fees was punitive in nature is without merit.Â  The only issue before the trial court was the assessment of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs to Seabrook.Â  There is no evidence the award was excessive or punitive in nature.Â  Seabrook presented ample evidence indicating it actually incurred the fees awarded.
II.Â  No Right to Testify 
Berger argues the trial court erred by requiring that he submit an affidavit contesting the reasonableness of Seabrookâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees, rather than allowing him to testify live at the hearing.Â  Berger further contends his live testimony would have better enabled him to address his objections to the attorneyâ€™s fees because Seabrookâ€™s attorney, Wheeler, was present and would have been able to clarify or respond to any matters in dispute.Â  
As a general rule, the admission of evidence is a matter addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Gamble v. Intâ€™l Paper Realty Corp. of South Carolina, 323 S.C. 367, 373, 474 S.E.2d 438, 441 (1996);Â  Hofer v. St. Clair, 298 S.C. 503, 513, 381 S.E.2d 736, 742 (1989);Â  R & G Constr., Inc. v. Lowcountry Regâ€™l Transp. Auth., 343 S.C. 424, 439, 540 S.E.2d 113, 121 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  On appeal, therefore, this Court will not disturb a trial courtâ€™s evidentiary rulings absent a clear abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â  at 439, 540 S.E.2d at 121; Elledge v. Richland/Lexington School Dist. Five, 352 S.C. 179, 185, 573 S.E.2d 789, 792 (2002); see also Whaley v. CSX Transp., Inc., 362 S.C. 456, 483, 609 S.E.2d 286, 300 (2005) (observing admission of evidence will not be reversed absent an abuse of discretion).Â  The trial judgeâ€™s decision will not be reversed on appeal unless it appears he clearly abused his discretion and the objecting party was prejudiced by the decision.Â  S.C. Prop. & Cas. Guar. Assâ€™n v. Yensen, 345 S.C. 512, 548 S.E.2d 880 (Ct. App. 2001); Sullivan v. Davis, 317 S.C. 462, 454 S.E.2d 907 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  â€œFor this Court to reverse a case based on the admission of evidence, both error and prejudice must be shown.â€Â  Stevens v. Allen, 336 S.C. 439, 448, 520 S.E.2d 625, 629 (Ct. App. 1999) (citing Timmons v. South Carolina Tricentennial Commâ€™n, 254 S.C. 378, 175 S.E.2d 805 (1970)).Â  
As a preliminary matter, we note that this case does not involve the exclusion of any of Bergerâ€™s proffered evidence; rather it concerns the manner in which he was allowed to present the evidence.Â  Considering that the trial judge is vested with discretion to admit or exclude evidence, a fortiori the trial judge may regulate the manner in which evidence is offered to the court, subject to review for abuse of discretion or error of law.Â  Accordingly, we reason that in contesting a trial judgeâ€™s regulation of the way in which testimony is presented, an appellant must show both error and prejudice.Â  Cf. Fields v. Regâ€™l Med. Center Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 26, 609 S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005) (citations omitted) (finding that to warrant a reversal based on the admission or exclusion of evidence, the appellant must prove both the error of the ruling and the resulting prejudice, i.e., that there is a reasonable probability the juryâ€™s verdict was influenced by the challenged evidence or the lack thereof); Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 525, 595 S.E.2d 817, 825 (Ct. App. 2004) (same); Rule 103, SCRE (providing that â€œ[e]rror may not be predicated upon a ruling which admits or excludes evidence unless a substantial right of the party is affected[.]â€).
Unlike in criminal cases, litigants in civil matters do not have a constitutionally guaranteed right to testify before the court.Â  In Faretta v. California, the United States Supreme Court observed that the Court has â€œoften recognized the constitutional stature of rights that, though not literally expressed in the document, are essential to due process of law in a fair adversary process.â€Â  422 U.S. 806, 819, n.15 (1975).Â  Among these rights is the right of â€œan accused . . . to testify on his own behalf[.]â€Â  Id. (citations omitted).Â  This guarantee pertains only to criminal cases, however.Â  â€œ[I]n the absence of due process concerns, there is no fundamental right to testify in a civil action.â€Â  Williams v. Chrysler Ins. Co., 928 P.2d 1375, 1381 (Colo. Ct. App. 1996). 
The South Carolina Supreme Court has addressed the award of attorneyâ€™s fees where a trial judge did not receive any evidence on the reasonableness of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  In Farmers & Merchants Bank v. Fargnoli, 274 S.C. 23, 260 S.E.2d 185 (1979), the court affirmed an award of attorneyâ€™s fees, even though the trial judge did not â€œreceiv[e] evidence as to the value of the services rendered.â€Â  Id. at 25-26, 260 S.E.2d at 187.Â  The Farmers court propounded:

As a general rule, the amount of attorney fees to be awarded in a particular case is within the discretion of the trial judge.Â  The law requires, however, that the award must be reasonable.Â  While there may be instances where the taking of evidence should be required in determining fees, we cannot say under the facts of this case that the amount awarded is unreasonable, or that it was error for the judge to award such an amount without evidentiary support.

Id. at 26, 260 S.E.2d at 187.Â  Subsequent decisions have emphasized the requirement that the record contain evidence supporting each of the six factors enumerated in Blumberg.Â  In Rowell v. Whisnant, 360 S.C. 181, 600 S.E.2d 96 (Ct. App. 2004), this Court explicated:

Trial courts make specific findings of fact on the record for each of the factors set out above [the Blumberg factors].Â  In fact, â€œ[o]n appeal, absent sufficient evidentiary support on the record for each factor, the award should be reversed and the issue remanded for the trial court to make specific findings of fact.â€Â  

Rowell, 360 S.C. at 186, 600 S.E.2d at 99 (quoting Blumberg, 310 S.C. at 494, 427 S.E.2d at 661).Â  
Thus, so long as the record supports each of the six factors for awarding attorneyâ€™s fees, a trial judgeâ€™s refusal to take any evidenceâ€”written or oralâ€”on the reasonableness of the fees is not necessarily erroneous.Â  In the instant case, the trial judge specifically addressed each of the Blumberg factors and concluded Seabrookâ€™s fees were reasonable.Â  Berger is unable to demonstrate to this Court that the trial judge erred, and we find no abuse of discretion in the trial judgeâ€™s decision to consider Bergerâ€™s testimony through an affidavit rather than live testimony.
Even were we to find error, Bergerâ€™s claim would still fail because he has not demonstrated prejudice resulting from the trial judgeâ€™s decision.Â  The judge did not exclude any evidence, and Berger cannot show he was prejudiced because his testimony was written rather than oral.Â  Although the trial judge did not permit Berger to testify in person, he allowed Berger to submit an affidavit up to twenty days after the hearing.Â  The affidavit provided Berger with a fair opportunity to offer complete, detailed testimony regarding his objections to the attorneyâ€™s fees. 
CONCLUSION
We rule that a trial judge in the exercise of discretion in an award of attorneyâ€™s fees under a contract between the parties is NOT required to take live testimony, provided the adverse party is allowed to present a full and complete presentation against the award of attorneyâ€™s fees by affidavits.Â  The record contains ample evidence to support the trial judgeâ€™s findings and his award of $39,194.08 in attorneyâ€™s fees in favor of Seabrook.Â  Therefore, the order of the trial judge is 
AFFIRMED. 
STILWELL and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

description: Appellants present several issues on appeal: (1)	Did the Millers perform and work overtime hours at Blumenthal Mills, Inc. so as to give efficacy to a FLSA claim? THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

Appellants,
v.
Blumenthal Mills, Inc.,

Appeal From Marion County
B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4013
Heard June 15, 2005 â€“ Filed July 5, 2005

AFFIRMED IN RESULT as to Ernest Miller;
REVERSED and REMANDED as to Patricia Miller


  
    
      
Chalmers C. Johnson, of Charleston, for Appellants.
Michael S. Thwaites, of Greer, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Â This appeal arises from the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to the employer in a case brought by employees pursuant to the Fair Labor Standards Act for unpaid overtime wages.Â  We affirm in result as to Ernest Miller.Â  We reverse and remand as to Patricia Miller.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Blumenthal Mills, Inc., is a textile manufacturer located in Marion, South Carolina.Â  Patricia Miller (Patricia) is employed by Blumenthal.Â  Ernest Miller (Ernest), Patriciaâ€™s husband, worked for Blumenthal before being terminated in May 2003 after a confrontation with a Blumenthal supervisor.Â  The Millers filed suit against Blumenthal alleging an unwritten plant rule required its workers to clock in approximately twenty minutes early every day to â€œperform . . . machine preparationâ€ or look over their work.Â  The Millers aver that during training, they were instructed to come in about twenty minutes before their shift started to check and make sure the prior shift left them in good shape.Â  The Millers were not paid for this extra time.Â  They contend the failure to pay overtime violates the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA).[1]
Blumenthal has a written policy contained in an employee handbook permitting its employees to clock in â€œa reasonable amount of time before the commencement of their shift.â€Â  Blumenthal asserts â€œ[t]his guideline is designed as a convenience to [employees] and to ease congestion at the time clock during starting and quitting times.â€Â  This policy prohibits employees from beginning any work-related activity before their regularly scheduled starting time, unless such activity is first approved in writing by management.
In order to provide a degree of exactitude in regard to the testimony of Patricia, we quote her deposition extensively:

Q.Â  It has down here, â€œToday had a meeting with Tim Richardson . . . . Tim also said I was doing a good job coming in early and checking my cloth.Â  Julia was in there with me.â€Â  Where was this meeting?
A.Â  In the supervisorâ€™s office.
Q.Â  Who is Julia?
A.Â  She is another weaver.Â  Julia Davis.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Q.Â  Now, the creelers, are they required to be there twenty minutes ahead of time?
A.Â  They have been told to get in there and check their job early to make sure everything was right.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .

A.Â  Yes.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Q.Â  How did you find out that you as a creeler were expected to be there early to check your work?

Q.Â  Who was that?
A.Â  Sylvia.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Q.Â  What exactly did Sylvia say to you?

Q.Â  Would she tell you how early to come in?
A.Â  She would say at least twenty minutes ahead of time.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Q.Â  Did you [later] go through a specific training course [to become a weaver]?
A.Â  Yes.
Q.Â  Who conducted that?
A.Â  Ms. Diane.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Q.Â  OK.Â  Tell me about your weaver training.Â  What did that involve?
A.Â  . . . Ms. Diane would say â€œYou comeâ€”need to comeâ€”be on your job at least twenty minutes ahead of time.â€
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Q.Â  . . . [Y]our testimony is that Diane told the entire weave class they had to come in twenty minutes early?
A.Â  Yes.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .

A.Â  Yes.
Q.Â  How long does it take you in an average dayâ€”how many lenos do you have to swap out?

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Q.Â  . . . And this coming in early has been the rule the whole time, is that right?
A.Â  Yes.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Q.Â  I mean, were you aware you werenâ€™t getting paid for this time?
A.Â  Yes, sir.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Q.Â  But, even with these written guidelines in place, it is your testimony that the real rule is that you do have to come in twenty minutes ahead of time and do prep work?

Q.Â  Who is they?

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Q.Â  . . . I want you to give me theâ€”a list of the names of any witness, any person who can provide first hand testimony that is can say that they have seen you perform work-related activity before your shift started?
A.Â  OK.Â  Julia Davis.
Q.Â  Let me write them down as we are going along.Â  Julia Davis. Â She still works there?
A.Â  Yes.Â  Jackie.Â  I donâ€™t know Jackieâ€™s last name.
Q.Â  What does Jackie do?
A.Â  Sheâ€™s a weaver.
Q.Â  On what shift?
A.Â  My shift.Â  Woody Church.Â  Was Roger Hilderbrand, but he ainâ€™t there no more.
Q.Â  All right.Â  Woody Church is your immediate supervisor?
A.Â  Yes.Â  And, he knows every morning when I clock in and when I go to my job, right along with Roger Hilderbrand, because I will be checking my cloth when Roger be doing his job and Roger will walk right by me.
Q.Â  OK.
A.Â  Tim Richardson, whenever Woody was out, he would come by and tap me on the shoulder and say, â€œGood job,â€ and keep right on getting it.Â Â  Deborah, James Wallace.
Q.Â  All right.Â  Whatâ€™s Deborahâ€™s last name?
A.Â  I do not know Deborahâ€™s last name.
Q.Â  She work there still?
A.Â  Yes.
Q.Â  Is she a weaver?
A.Â  Yes.
Q.Â  On your shift?
A.Â  Yes.
Q.Â  OK.Â  Iâ€™m sorry.Â  The next person.
A.Â  James Wallace, Tim Martin.
Q.Â  James Wallace is a weaver?
A.Â  Well, heâ€™s a smash hand now.

The third factor that must be considered is the size of the aggregate claim.Â  Id. at 1063.Â  Courts have granted relief for claims that might have been minimal on a daily basis but, when aggregated, amounted to a substantial claim.Â  Id.Â  The fourth factor that must be considered in applying the de minimis rule is whether the employee performed the work on a regular basis.Â  Id.; see also 29 C.F.R. Â§ 785.47 (noting that employer should compensate â€œfixed or regularâ€ working time, however small).
â€œTo summarize, in determining whether otherwise compensable time is de minimis, we will consider (1) the practical administrative difficulty of recording the additional time; (2) the aggregate amount of compensable time; and (3) the regularity of the additional work.â€Â  Lindow, 738 F.2d at 1063.
Applying the Lindow factors to the case at bar, jury issues are presented as to whether: (1) the time is easily recorded on the actual time cards of Patricia; (2) twenty minutes, factored in the aggregate, is a de minimis amount of time; and (3) the work is performed regularly and is not a sporadic requirement.Â  
IV.Â  FLSA Designed to Protect Employees
The FLSA was designed to protect employees.Â  In Brooklyn Savings Bank v. Oâ€™Neil, 324 U.S. 697 (1945), the Supreme Court articulated:

The legislative history of the Fair Labor Standards Act shows an intent on the part of Congress to protect certain groups of the population from substandard wages and excessive hours which endangered the national health and well-being and the free flow of goods in interstate commerce.Â  The statute was a recognition of the fact that due to the unequal bargaining power as between employer and employee, certain segments of the population required federal compulsory legislation to prevent private contracts on their part which endangered national health and efficiency and as a result the free movement of goods in interstate commerce. To accomplish this purpose standards of minimum wages and maximum hours were provided.

Id. at 706-07 (footnotes omitted).Â  Doe v. United States, 372 F.3d 1347 (Fed. Cir. 2004), clarifies that employers cannot escape liability if they permit or suffer an employee to work overtime.Â  Id. at 1360-61; see also 29 C.F.R. 185.11 (noting that work not requested but suffered or permitted is work time).
V.Â  Ernest Millerâ€™s Claim
In contrariety to the deposition of Patricia, the deposition of Ernest is imbued with generalities, lack of particularity, vagueness, and inexactitude in regard to any mandatory, specific pre-shift activities.Â  The conclusory and non-specific testimony of Ernest fails to survive the grant of summary judgment.Â  We agree with the circuit judge in his grant of summary judgment as to all claims of Ernest.
CONCLUSION
Amalgamating our analysis of the FLSA, the Portal-to-Portal Act, the de minimis rule, and policy aspects of the FLSA, we come to the ineluctable conclusion that the grant of summary judgment as to the claim of Patricia Miller is erroneous and is reversed.Â  We affirm the grant of summary judgment as to all claims of Ernest.Â  Accordingly, the trial judgeâ€™s order granting summary judgment as to Ernest Miller is AFFIRMED IN RESULT and REVERSED and REMANDED as to Patricia Miller.
AFFIRMED IN RESULT as to Ernest Miller; REVERSED and REMANDED as to Patricia Miller.
 STILWELL and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

description: On August 2, 2001, Collins Music Co., Inc. was awarded a jury verdict against IGT a/k/a IGT-North America in the amount of  Fifteen Million and No/100 ($15,000,000.00) Dollars.  A judgment was entered in the office of the Clerk of Court for Horry County in the sum of Fifteen Million and No/100 ($15,000,000.00) Dollars on August 3, 2001. Collins argues: (1)	Section 34-31-20(B), as amended, left intact the legal rate of Fourteen (14%) Percent interest on the Collinsâ€™ judgment; and (2)	All issues are moot because IGT a/k/a IGT-North America paid the sum of Twenty Million Six Hundred Three Thousand Eight Hundred Thirty One and 08/100 ($20,603,831.08) Dollars in satisfaction of judgment in Nevada.
