text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Collins Music Co., Inc., Respondent,
v.
IGT a/k/a IGT- North America, Appellant.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 4015
Heard June 16, 2005 â€“ Filed July 18, 2005

AFFIRMED

Appeal From Horry County
Â John L.Â  Breeden, Circuit Court Judge


  
    
      
R. Wayne Byrd, Wilson S. Sheldon, and R. Heath Atkinson, all of Florence and Ronald E. Boston, of Columbia, for Appellant.
James B. Van Osdell, Charles B. Jordan, Jr., and Cynthia Graham Howe, all of Myrtle Beach, James R. Gilreath, of Greenville and Scott M. Mongillo, of Summerville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: The Horry County Clerk of Court issued a Transcript of Judgment, and subsequently an Amended Transcript of Judgment, in furtherance of Collins Music Co., Inc.â€™s (Collins) right to enforce in Nevada a judgment obtained against IGT.Â  IGT appeals from the trial courtâ€™s order denying its Rule 60(a), SCRCP motion to vacate the Amended Transcript of Judgment on the ground it improperly provides for post-judgment interest at the rate of fourteen percent (14%).Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Collins originally brought suit in 1994 against IGT asserting multiple causes of action arising from a contractual dispute.Â  A jury returned a verdict of $15,000,000 in actual damages in favor of Collins.Â  This Court dismissed IGTâ€™s appeal as untimely.Â  See Collins Music Co., Inc. v. IGT, 353 S.C. 559, 579 S.E.2d 524 (Ct. App. 2002).
Collins sought to enforce the judgment in Nevada pursuant to the Uniform Enforcement of Foreign Judgments Act, Nev. Rev. Stat. Â§ 17.330-17.400.Â  On January 14, 2002, the Horry County Clerk of Court issued a Transcript of Judgment.Â  It provided for interest accruing at the rate of twelve percent (12%) per year.Â  Thereafter, upon request by Collins, the Clerk of Court issued an Amended Transcript of Judgment.Â  The amended transcript provided:

Interest accrues on South Carolina judgments (from causes of action arising prior [sic] January 1, 2001) at the rate of 14% per annum.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 34-31-20(B) (2002 Cum. Supp.)Â  This cause of action was filed in 1994 so the 14% interest rate applies. 

(Emphasis in original.)
Collins filed the Amended Transcript of Judgment with the Nevada court on August 14, 2003, along with a supporting affidavit from Collinsâ€™ counsel.Â  A copy of the amended transcript was sent to IGTâ€™s Nevada counsel.
In September 2003, IGT filed and served its Rule 60(a), SCRCP motion seeking an order withdrawing and vacating the Amended Transcript of Judgment. Â The court denied the motion on February 20, 2004, and IGT appealed on March 18, 2004.
On March 24, 2004, IGT filed its motion for Leave to Deposit Money with Court in the Nevada action.Â  IGT deposited the money with the Nevada court on April 2, 2004, and the Nevada court issued an Order for Disbursement of Funds in Satisfaction of Judgment on April 5.Â  IGT did not appeal this order, and the funds were subsequently paid to Collins.
LAW/ANALYSIS
IGT contends the trial court erred in failing to vacate and withdraw the Amended Transcript of Judgment.Â  IGT asserts section 34-31-20 of the South Carolina Code, as amended by 2000 Act No. 344, does not allow for the collection of interest where a cause of action arose prior to January 2001, but final judgment was not rendered until after January 2001.Â  In the alternative, IGT maintains the appropriate statutory interest is twelve percent (12%) and not fourteen percent (14%).Â  We disagree.
I.Â  Mootness
First, Collins contends the issue is moot and not available for review on appeal because IGT made the payment to the Nevada court prior to this appeal.Â  We disagree.Â  
A matter becomes moot â€œwhen judgment, if rendered, will have no practical legal effect upon [the] existing controversy.Â  This is true when some event occurs making it impossible for [the] reviewing Court to grant effectual relief.â€Â  Curtis v. State, 345 S.C. 557, 567-68, 549 S.E.2d 591, 596 (2001) (alteration in original) (quoting Mathis v. South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t, 260 S.C. 344, 346, 195 S.E.2d 713, 715 (1973)), cert. denied, 535 U.S. 926 (2002).Â  In civil cases, there are three exceptions to the mootness doctrine: (1) an appellate court can retain jurisdiction if the issue is capable of repetition yet evading review, (2) an appellate court can decide cases of urgency to establish a rule for future conduct in matters of important public interest, and (3) if the decision by the trial court can affect future events or have collateral consequences to the parties, the appellate court can take jurisdiction.Â  Curtis at 568, 549 S.E.2d at 596.
In the instant case, the third exception to the mootness doctrine is applicable.Â  If IGT failed to make payment, the amount of interest charged against IGT would continue to increase.Â  It would be nonsensical to require IGT to incur an ever-increasing amount of post-judgment interest in order to bring an appeal.Â  As a result, we find this Court retains jurisdiction to hear this case and to decide the issue regarding post-judgment interest.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Statutory Construction
â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.â€Â  Hawkins v. Bruno Yacht Sales, Inc., 353 S.C. 31, 39, 577 S.E.2d 202, 207 (2003); Bayle v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 122, 542 S.E.2d 736, 739 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œAll rules of statutory construction are subservient to the one that the legislative intent must prevail if it reasonably can be discovered in the language used, and the language must be construed in the light of the intended purpose of the statute.â€Â  City of Sumter Police Depâ€™t v. One (1) 1992 Blue Mazda Truck (VIN # jm2uf1132n0294812), 330 S.C. 371, 375, 498 S.E.2d 894, 896 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œStatutes, as a whole, must receive practical, reasonable, and fair interpretation, consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of lawmakers.â€Â  TNS Mills, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611, 624, 503 S.E.2d 471, 478 (1998).Â Â  
If a statuteâ€™s language is plain, unambiguous, and conveys a clear meaning, â€œthe rules of statutory interpretation are not needed and the court has no right to impose another meaning.â€Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  The words of the statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.Â  Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992).Â  â€œOur goal in construing statutes is to prevent an interpretation that would lead to a result that is plainly absurd.â€Â  In re Timothy C.M., 348 S.C. 653, 655-56, 560 S.E.2d 452, 453 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing Florence County v. Moore, 344 S.C. 596, 601, 545 S.E.2d 507, 509 (2001)); Carolina Alliance for Fair Employment v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Lic., & Reg., 337 S.C. 476, 492, 523 S.E.2d 795, 803 (Ct. App. 1999).
The legislature has sought to ensure amended statutes are not read in a way that leads to an absurd result.Â  Section 2-7-50 of the South Carolina Code provides:

Whenever, in any act, reference is made to this Code for the purpose of altering, amending, adding to or repealing any part thereof, such reference, alteration, amendment, addition or repeal shall be construed to apply to the original law purporting to be revised in such revision as fully and specifically as though such original laws were mentioned in the act containing such reference, alteration, amendment, addition or repeal.Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 2-7-50 (1976).
A brief but relevant look at the history of the right to interest on judgments is edifying for the instant case.Â  

According to the common law the execution could only issue for the precise sum adjudged to be due to the plaintiff, however long the enforcement of it might be postponed, although in a new action he might recover the interest. The act of 1815 was intended to remedy this evil; it provides, â€œthat in all judgments and decrees of the courts of law and equity hereafter to be obtained and rendered on any judgment, bond, bill or promissory note, or other cause of action bearing interest, the principal sum of the judgment, bondâ€ &c. â€œshall continue to bear the same interest as the original cause of action did bear before the entry of judgment thereon,â€ and that execution should issue
therefor.

Richardson v. Richardson, 16 S.C.Eq. (McMul.Eq.) 103 (1841); see also Sears v. Fowler, 293 S.C. 43, 45, 358 S.E.2d 574, 575 (1987) (noting that at common law, judgments did not bear interest) (citing Annot., 15 A.L.R.3d 411, 414 (1967)).Â  Interest is generally allowable pursuant to statutory enactments.Â  Sears, 293 S.C. at 45, 358 S.E.2d at 575.
Section 34-31-20(B)â€™s predecessor provided: â€œall money decrees and judgments of courts enrolled or entered . . . shall draw interest according to law, the legal interest shall be at the rate of six percent per annum.â€Â  S.C. Code Â§ 8-2 (1962).Â  The six percent (6%) rate was carried over into the 1976 Code, and in 1979, the rate was changed to eight and three-fourths percent (8.75%).Â  See 1979 Act No. 159.Â  Effective June 9, 1982, the rate was increased to fourteen percent (14%).Â  1982 Act No. 445; see also Southeastern Freight Lines v. Michelin Tire Corp., 279 S.C. 174, 175, 303 S.E.2d 860, 861 (1983).Â  The 1982 Act included a statement regarding the effective date: â€œThis act shall take effect upon approval by the Governor.â€Â  1982 Act No. 445, Â§ 2.
In Southeastern Freight Lines, the South Carolina Supreme Court considered the impact of the 1982 Act on a judgment entered before the effective date, but not satisfied until after the date of the changed interest rate.Â  Southeastern Freight Lines v. Michelin Tire Corp., 279 S.C. 174, 175, 303 S.E.2d 860, 861 (1983).Â  Finding the change in interest rate applied to all judgments, even those entered before the effective date but not yet satisfied, the court determined interest would be charged at eight and three-fourths percent (8.75%) before June 9 and fourteen percent (14%) after June 9, 1982.Â  Id. at 175-76, 303 S.E.2d at 861-62.
At issue in the instant case are the changes to the interest rate made effective by 2000 Act No. 344.Â  Section 34-31-20(B), prior to January 2001, provided: â€œAll money decrees and judgments of courts enrolled or entered shall draw interest according to law.Â  The legal interest shall be at the rate of fourteen percent per annum.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 34-31-20(B) (Supp. 1999).Â  Between January 1, 2001 and March 21, 2005, section 34-31-20(B) read: â€œAll money decrees and judgments of courts enrolled or entered shall draw interest according to law.Â  The legal interest is at the rate of twelve percent a year.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 34-31-20(B) (Supp. 2004).Â  Indubitably, the only change to the law was the certain rate allowed for interest.
The 2000 Act provided the following effective date:Â  â€œThis act takes effect January 1, 2001, and applies with respect to interest calculated pursuant to causes of action arising or accruing on or after that date.â€Â  2000 Act No. 344, Â§ 4.Â  The question before this Court is whether this provision requires a finding that a litigant in a case in which the cause of action arose before the effective date of January 1, 2001, but where judgment was not rendered until after that date, must forfeit the right to post-judgment interest.Â  
Reading section 2-7-50 in conjunction with the 2000 Act and section 34-31-20, it is apodictic that the legislature intended there to be continuity in the charge of interest to judgments.Â  Nothing in the 2000 Act indicates the legislature sought to create an aperture in coverage, thus eliminating from entitlement to interest litigants in cases accruing before January 1, 2001 but pending final judgment until after January 1, 2001.Â  For this Court to construe the effective date section of the 2000 Act as eliminating interest based solely on what date a final judgment is rendered would constitute an absurd result.Â  
Collinsâ€™ cause of action arose prior to January 1, 2001.Â  Under the clear, unambiguous wording of the 2000 Actâ€™s effective date section, the new interest rate does not apply.Â  The version of section 34-31-20(B) that existed prior to the 2000 Act remained in effect and was not repealed by the passage of the 2000 amendment.Â  We refuse to arbitrarily deny interest to Collins because of the date its judgment was entered.Â  Concomitantly, Collins is entitled to receive interest of its judgment against IGT.
In the instant case, unlike the Southeastern Freight Lines case, the 2000 Act included a statement denoting which judgments were affected by the new interest rate.Â  The effective date provision clearly indicates it applies only to causes of action arising or accruing on or after January 1, 2001.Â  Thus, the fourteen percent (14%) rate under the pre-2000 Act statute applies to Collinsâ€™ judgment, and the amount does not change as a result of the 2000 Act.
Finally, we note that in the 2005 session, the legislature again amended section 34-31-20(B).Â  However, the 2005 amendment has no bearing on the disposition of this case.Â  Section 34-31-20(B) now reads:

A money decree or judgment of a court enrolled or entered must draw interest according to law.Â  The legal rate of interest is equal to the prime rate as listed in the first edition of the Wall Street Journal published for each calendar year for which the damages are awarded, plus four percentage points, compounded annually.Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court shall issue an order by January 15 of each year confirming the annual prime rate.Â  This section applies to all judgments entered on or after July 1, 2005.Â  For judgments entered between July 1, 2005, and January 14, 2006, the legal rate shall be the first prime rate as published in the first edition of the Wall Street Journal after January 1, 2005, plus four percentage points.

2005 Act No. 27.Â Â  
CONCLUSION
We rule the fourteen percent (14%) rate applies to all causes of action arising between June 9, 1982 and December 31, 2000, whether or not a final judgment was entered prior to January 1, 2001.Â  The order of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

description: The issue on appeal is whether the Circuit Court erred in affirming the Probate Courtâ€™s finding that Trustee Moran â€“ not Appellant University â€“ was the â€œcompetent person . . . having beneficial interests . . . affected by the compromiseâ€ under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-1102 (1987). Stated differently, the issue is whether Appellant University of Southern California, which is the sole remainder beneficiary of the revocable trust, is a necessary party to that Compromise and Settlement Agreement.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
University of Southern California,
Appellant,
v.
Robert J. Moran, Jr., Personal Representative of the Estate of Alexia Lee Anderson, and Trustee of the Anderson Revocable Trust of 1990, dated the 15th day of September, 1991, Louis A. Chubiz and Michael J.
Chubiz, Respondents.
In Re:
Louis A. Chubiz and Michael J. Chubiz, Petitioners,
v.
Robert J. Moran, Jr., Personal Representative of the Estate of Alexia Lee Anderson, and Trustee of the Anderson Revocable Trust of 1990, dated the 15th day of September, 1991,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4016
Heard June 15, 2005 â€“ Filed July 18, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert M. Kunes, of Charleston, for Appellant.
James B. Drennan, III, of Spartanburg, and Ronald Stewart Gaynor, of Pawleyâ€™s Island, for Respondents.
      
    
  

__________
ANDERSON, J.:Â  Robert Moran, as trustee of the Anderson Trust, entered into a compromise agreement with Louis and Michael Chubiz, which was approved by the probate court.Â  On appeal from the probate court, the circuit court affirmed.Â  The University of Southern California, as a beneficiary of the Anderson Trust, appeals the order of the circuit court.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
As part of their estate plan, Alexia Anderson and her husband, Thomas Anderson, executed pour-over wills and created a joint revocable trust, referred to by the parties as the â€œAnderson Trust.â€Â  The Andersons left their entire estates, other than tangible personal property, to the Anderson Trust.Â  The provisions of the trust agreement provided upon the death of the first spouse, all property would remain in trust for the benefit of the surviving spouse.Â  Upon the death of the surviving spouse, the trustee would make nine cash distributions from the trustâ€”$50,000 to be held in trust for the care of the coupleâ€™s dog and $10,000 to each of their eight named nieces and nephews.Â  Under the trust agreement, the remaining amount in the trust was to be distributed to the University of Southern California (the University).Â  
Mrs. Anderson died shortly after her husbandâ€™s death, leaving approximately $4,436,000 to be distributed through the trust. Â Robert Moran, an attorney, was appointed as the personal representative of both estates and the successor trustee of the Anderson Trust.Â  After his appointment, Moran flew to Minnesota for the Andersonsâ€™ memorial service.Â  While in Minnesota, Moran informed the Andersonsâ€™ nieces and nephews, including Louis Chubiz and Michael Chubiz, that they would receive $10,000 distributions from the Anderson Trust.Â  
The Chubizes threatened to contest Mrs. Andersonâ€™s will and the Anderson Trust on the ground that the documents were the product of undue influence.Â  Based on this threat, Moran and the Chubizes negotiated a compromise agreement in which Mrs. Andersonâ€™s estate agreed to pay both of the Chubizes $175,000.Â  Moran signed the agreement in his capacity as trustee of the Anderson Trust, but refused to sign it as personal representative of Mrs. Andersonâ€™s estate unless the probate court approved the agreement.Â  The Chubizes filed a petition in the probate court seeking approval of the compromise agreement pursuant to sections 62-3-1101 and -1102 of the South Carolina Code (1987 & Supp. 2004).Â  The University received notice of the proposed compromise agreement and filed a motion opposing it.Â Â  
The probate court heard the Universityâ€™s motion and issued an order finding the requirements of section 62-3-1102 had been met.Â  The probate court ruled: (1) the agreement was the result of a good-faith controversy; and (2) Moran as trustee, not the University, was the holder of the beneficial interest affected by the compromise agreement.Â Â Â  
The University appealed the probate courtâ€™s order to the circuit court, arguing the probate court erred in finding both a good-faith controversy existed and the University was not a holder of a beneficial interest.Â  The University maintained its signature was required for judicial approval of the compromise agreement.Â  Following a hearing, the circuit court issued an order affirming the probate court.Â  The University appeals only the issue of whether it was a holder of a beneficial interest.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAppeal from the probate court is governed by the provisions of the Probate Code.â€Â 
In re Howard,
315 S.C. 356, 360, 434 S.E.2d 254, 256 (1993).Â  The Probate Code requires appeals from the probate court be to the circuit court.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-308 (Supp. 2004).Â  The Probate Code further instructs the circuit court to â€œhear and determine the appeal according to the rules of law.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-308(d) (Supp. 2004).Â  â€œAs used in this statute, the phrase â€˜according to the rules of lawâ€™ means according to the rules governing appeals.â€Â  In re Howard, 315 S.C. at 360, 434 S.E.2d at 257.Â  â€œ[I]f there is neither a statute nor a rule of court expressly prescribing a different standard of review, the circuit court must apply the same standard that [the appellate court] would apply were the appeal taken directly to either [the supreme court or court of appeals].â€Â  Id. at 361, 434 S.E.2d at 257. 
The standard of review applicable to cases originating in the probate court depends upon whether the underlying cause of action is at law or in equity.Â  In re Estate of Hyman, 362 S.C. 20, 25, 606 S.E.2d 205, 207 (Ct. App. 2004); In re Thames, 344 S.C. 564, 568, 544 S.E.2d 854, 856 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  An issue regarding statutory interpretation is a question of law.Â 
Wimberly v. Barr, 359 S.C. 414, 597 S.E.2d 853 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Thus, â€œthe circuit court may not disturb the probate courtâ€™s findings of fact unless a review of the record discloses there is no evidence to support them.â€Â  In re Howard, 315 S.C. at 361, 434 S.E.2d at 257; see also In re Estate of Pallister, 363 S.C. 437, ___, 611 S.E.2d 250, 256 (2005) (â€œIf the proceeding in the probate court is in the nature of an action at law, the circuit court and the appellate court may not disturb the probate courtâ€™s findings of fact unless a review of the record discloses there is no evidence to support them.â€).Â  The standard of review at law is the same whether the facts are found by a jury or the judge sitting without a jury.Â  In re Howard, 315 S.C. at 361, 434 S.E.2d at 257.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The University argues the probate court and the circuit court erred in finding the compromise agreement entered into by Moran, as trustee, and the Chubizes met the requirements of sections 62-3-1101 and -1102 of the South Carolina Code.Â  Specifically, the University contends it held a beneficial interest in Mrs. Andersonâ€™s estate.Â  Therefore, the University asserts its signature was necessary to meet the requirements set forth in section 62-3-1102 for court approval of a compromise of a controversy regarding a decedentâ€™s estate.Â  We disagree. 
I.Â  Rules of Statutory Construction
The cardinal rule of statutory interpretation is to determine the intent of the legislature.Â  Bass v. Isochem, Op. No. 3996 (S.C. Ct. App. filed June 6, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 24 at 42); Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds, Inc. v. County of Aiken, 354 S.C. 18, 579 S.E.2d 334 (Ct. App. 2003); see also Gordon v. Phillips Utils., Inc., 362 S.C. 403, 406, 608 S.E.2d 425, 427 (2005) (â€œThe primary purpose in construing a statute is to ascertain legislative intent.â€).Â  All rules of statutory construction are subservient to the one that legislative intent must prevail if it can be reasonably discovered in the language used, and that language must be construed in the light of the intended purpose of the statute.Â  McClanahan v. Richland County Council, 350 S.C. 433, 567 S.E.2d 240 (2002); Ray Bell Constr. Co. v. School Dist. of Greenville County, 331 S.C. 19, 501 S.E.2d 725 (1998).
The legislatureâ€™s intent should be ascertained primarily from the plain language of the statute.Â  Bass v. Isochem, Op. No. 3996 (S.C. Ct. App. filed June 6, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 24 at 42); State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 606 S.E.2d 503 (Ct. App. 2004); Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 478 S.E.2d 74 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The language must also be read in a sense which harmonizes with its subject matter and accords with its general purpose.Â  Mun. Assâ€™n of South Carolina v. AT&T Communications of S. States, Inc., 361 S.C. 576, 606 S.E.2d 468 (2004); Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 420 S.E.2d 843 (1992).Â  The courtâ€™s primary function in interpreting a statute is to ascertain the intent of the General Assembly.Â  Smith v. South Carolina Ins. Co., 350 S.C. 82, 564 S.E.2d 358 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œOnce the legislature has made [a] choice, there is no room for the courts to impose a different judgment based upon their own notions of public policy.â€Â  South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Mumford, 299 S.C. 14, 19, 382 S.E.2d 11, 14 (Ct. App. 1989).
When a statuteâ€™s terms are clear and unambiguous on their face, there is no room for statutory construction and a court must apply the statute according to its
literal meaning.Â  Miller v. Aiken, Op. No. 25976 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed May 2, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 19 at 16); Carolina Power & Light Co. v. City of Bennettsville, 314 S.C. 137, 442 S.E.2d 177 (1994).Â  If a statuteâ€™s language is unambiguous and clear, there is no need to employ the rules of statutory construction and this Court has no right to look for or impose another meaning.Â  Tilley v. Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 361, 585 S.E.2d 292 (2003); Paschal v. State Election Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 434, 454 S.E.2d 890 (1995); see also City of Camden v. Brassell, 326 S.C. 556, 561, 486 S.E.2d 492, 495 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œWhere the language of the statute is clear and explicit, the court cannot rewrite the statute and inject matters into it which are not in the legislatureâ€™s language.â€).Â  What a legislature says in the text of a statute is considered the best evidence of the legislative intent or will.Â  Bayle v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 542 S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The words of a statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction.Â  Durham v. United Companies Fin. Corp., 331 S.C. 600, 503 S.E.2d 465 (1998); Adkins v. Comcar Indus., Inc., 323 S.C. 409, 475 S.E.2d 762 (1996); Worsley Companies v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 351 S.C. 97, 567 S.E.2d 907 (Ct. App. 2002); see also Timmons v. South Carolina Tricentennial Commâ€™n, 254 S.C. 378, 175 S.E.2d 805 (1970) (observing that where the language of the statute is clear and explicit, the court cannot rewrite the statute and inject matters into it that are not in the legislatureâ€™s language).Â  Under the plain meaning rule, it is not the courtâ€™s place to change the meaning of a clear and unambiguous statute.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 533 S.E.2d 578 (2000); Bayle, 344 S.C. at 122, 542 S.E.2d at 739.
If the language of an act gives rise to doubt or uncertainty as to legislative intent, the construing court may search for that intent beyond the borders of the act itself.Â  Liberty
Mut. Ins. Co. v. South Carolina Second Injury Fund, 363 S.C. 612, ___, 611 S.E.2d 297, 303 (Ct. App. 2005); see also Wade v. Berkeley County, 348 S.C. 224, 229, 559 S.E.2d 586, 588 (2002) (â€œ[W]here a statute is ambiguous, the Court must construe the terms of the statute.â€).Â  An ambiguity in a statute should be resolved in favor of a just, beneficial, and equitable operation of the law.Â  City of Sumter Police Depâ€™t v. One (1) 1992 Blue Mazda Truck, 330 S.C. 371, 498 S.E.2d 894 (Ct. App. 1998); Brassell, 326 S.C. at 561, 486 S.E.2d at 495.Â  In construing a statute, the court looks to the language as a whole in light of its manifest purpose.Â  State v. Dawkins, 352 S.C. 162, 573 S.E.2d 783 (2002); Adams v. Texfi Indus., 320 S.C. 213, 464 S.E.2d 109 (1995); Brassell, 326 S.C. at 560, 486 S.E.2d at 494.
When faced with an undefined statutory term, the court must interpret the term in accord with its usual and customary meaning.Â  Branch v. City of Myrtle Beach, 340 S.C. 405, 532 S.E.2d 289 (2000); Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 504 S.E.2d 117 (1998); see also Santee Cooper Resort v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 298 S.C. 179, 184, 379 S.E.2d 119, 122 (1989) (â€œWords used in a statute should be taken in their ordinary and popular significance unless there is something in the statute requiring a different interpretation.â€).Â  â€œThe terms must be construed in context and their meaning determined by looking at the other terms used in the statute.â€Â  Hinton v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Prob., Parole and Pardon Servs., 357 S.C. 327, 332-33, 592 S.E.2d 335, 338 (Ct. App. 2004), cert. dismissed (June 6, 2005) (citing S. Mut. Church Ins. Co. v. South Carolina Windstorm & Hail Underwriting Assâ€™n, 306 S.C. 339, 342, 412 S.E.2d 377, 379 (1991)).
A statute as a whole must receive a practical, reasonable, and fair interpretation consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of the lawmakers.Â  See Liberty
Mut. Ins. Co., 363 S.C. 612, 611 S.E.2d 297 (Ct. App. 2005); see also Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds, 354 S.C. at 22, 579 S.E.2d at 336 (â€œA statute should be given a reasonable and practical construction consistent with the purpose and policy expressed in the statute.â€).Â  The real purpose and intent of the lawmakers will prevail over the literal import of the words.Â  Browning v. Hartvigsen, 307 S.C. 122, 414 S.E.2d 115 (1992).
Courts will reject a statutory interpretation which would lead to a result so plainly absurd that it could not have been intended by the legislature or would defeat the plain legislative intention.Â  Unisun Ins. Co. v. Schmidt, 339 S.C. 362, 529 S.E.2d 280 (2000); Kiriakides v. United Artists Communications, Inc., 312 S.C. 271, 440 S.E.2d 364 (1994).Â  A court should not consider a particular clause in a statute as being construed in isolation, but should read it in conjunction with the purpose of the whole statute and the policy of the law.Â  See Liberty Mut. Ins. Co., 336 S.C. at ___, 611 S.E.2d at 302; see also Mid-State Auto Auction v. Altman, 324 S.C. 65, 476 S.E.2d 690 (1996) (stating that in ascertaining the intent of the legislature, a court should not focus on any single section or provision but should consider the language of the statute as a whole).
II.Â  Sections 62-3-1101 and 62-3-1102
Section 62-3-1101 of the South Carolina Code, addressing court approval of agreements involving estates, provides: 

A compromise of a controversy as to admission to probate of an instrument offered for formal probate as the will of a decedent, the construction, validity, or effect of a probated will, the rights or interests in the estate of the decedent, of a successor, or the administration of the estate, if approved in a formal proceeding in the court for that purpose, is binding on all the parties including those unborn, unascertained, or who could not be located.Â  An approved compromise is binding even though it may affect a trust or an inalienable interest.Â  A compromise does not impair the rights of creditors or of taxing authorities who are not parties to it.Â  A compromise approved pursuant to this section is not a settlement of a claim subject to the provisions of Section 62-5-433.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-1101 (Supp. 2004) (emphasis added).Â  Section 62-3-1102 of the South Carolina Code states: 

The procedure for securing court approval of a compromise is as follows:
  
(1) The terms of the compromise shall be set forth in an agreement in writing which shall be executed by all competent persons and parents acting for any minor child having beneficial interests or having claims which will or may be affected by the compromise.Â  Execution is not required by any person whose identity cannot be ascertained or whose whereabouts is unknown and cannot reasonably be ascertained.
(2) Any interested person, including the personal representative or a trustee, then may submit the agreement to the court for its approval and for execution by the personal representative, the trustee of every affected testamentary trust, and other fiduciaries and representatives.
(3) After notice to all interested persons or their representatives, including the personal representative of the estate and all affected trustees of trusts, the court, if it finds that the contest or controversy is in good faith and that the effect of the agreement upon the interests of persons represented by fiduciaries or other representatives is just and reasonable, shall make an order approving the agreement and directing all fiduciaries subject to its jurisdiction to execute the agreement. Minor children represented only by their parents may be bound only if their parents join with other competent persons in execution of the compromise.Â  Upon the making of the order and the execution of the agreement, all further disposition of the estate is in accordance with the terms of the agreement.
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-1102 (1987) (emphasis added).Â  The Reporterâ€™s Comments to this section provide: â€œThe agreement must be signed by all persons having a beneficial interest in or claim against the estate, whose interest or claim is affected by the agreement.Â  If an interested party is a minor, the agreement may be executed on his behalf by his parent.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-1102 Reporterâ€™s Comments (1987) (emphasis added).Â  
Section 62-3-1102 allows competent persons having beneficial interests to enter into a written, court-approved settlement.Â  The settlement, or compromise, is valid and binding where the court finds (1) the controversy is in good faith, and (2) the agreementâ€™s effect is just and reasonable.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-1102(3) (1987).Â  The issue in the instant case does not pertain to these two statutory requirements, but rather to the prerequisite mandate that the written agreement be executed by all competent persons having a beneficial interest.Â  
The term â€œbeneficial interestâ€ is not defined in the Probate Code.Â  Section 62-1-201(2) defines â€œbeneficiaryâ€ as follows:Â  â€œâ€˜Beneficiaryâ€™, as it relates to trust beneficiaries, includes a person who has any present or future interest, vested or contingent, and also includes the owner of an interest by assignment or other transfer and, as it relates to a charitable trust, includes any person entitled to enforce the trust.â€Â  This definition, as indicated, only defines the term to the extent it relates to trust beneficiaries and does not address â€œbeneficiariesâ€ of a decedentâ€™s estate.Â  
In the context of section 62-3-1102, â€œcompetent persons . . . having beneficial interestsâ€ refers to a beneficial interest in the decedentâ€™s estate.Â  Therefore, the central question here is not who holds the beneficial interest in the Anderson Trust, but who has the beneficial interest in Mrs. Andersonâ€™s estate.Â  
Several provisions of the Probate Code support the Chubizesâ€™ reading of section 62-3-1102 that the trust holds the beneficial interest in Mrs. Andersonâ€™s estate.Â  Section 62-1-201(8) defines â€œdeviseeâ€ as â€œany person designated in a will to receive a devise.Â  In the case of a devise to an existing trust or trustee, or to a trustee on trust described by will, the trust or trustee is the devisee and the beneficiaries are not devisees.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-201(8) (1987) (emphasis added).Â  Section 62-1-403 provides that, absent a conflict of interest, â€œorders binding a trustee bind beneficiaries of the trust in proceedings to probate a will establishing or adding to a trust to review the acts or accounts of a prior fiduciary and in proceedings involving creditors or other third parties[.]â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-403(2)(ii) (1987).Â  
That the trust is an entity and not an individual is of no concern as the Probate Code defines â€œpersonâ€ as â€œan individual, a corporation, an organization or other legal entity.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-201(29) (1987).Â  Moran signed the compromise agreement in his capacity as trustee of the Anderson Trust.Â  
Policy considerations weigh in favor of ruling the trust is the person having the beneficial interest in Mrs. Andersonâ€™s estate.Â  â€œ[F]amily settlements are favored by the courts[.]â€Â  Dibble v. Dibble, 248 S.C. 165, 171, 149 S.E.2d 355, 358 (1966).Â  Our reading of section 62-3-1102 allows the trustee to resolve a dispute and thereby avoid a will contest that would significantly alter the deceasedâ€™s stated intent.Â  Under the Universityâ€™s interpretation of section 62-3-1102, one of many trust beneficiaries could exercise veto power over an attempted compromise under section 62-3-1102.Â  By failing to consent as a signatory of a settlement, trust beneficiaries would encourage litigation rather than settlement.Â  The better approach is to vest the trustee, who has a fiduciary obligation to administer the trust in the best interests of the trust beneficiaries, with the power to enter into the compromise on behalf of the trust.Â  
Indeed, both the Anderson Trust and the Probate Code give the trustee the power to enter into settlements.Â  The trust agreement enumerates various powers of the trustee.Â  Included in these powers is: (1) the power to â€œabandon, compromise, arbitrate or otherwise deal with and settle claims in favor of or against our estate and any trust created hereunder as may be deemed advisable by our trusteeâ€ and (2) the discretionary power to â€œdo all such acts and exercise all such rights and privileges, although not specifically listed hereunder, which our trustee deems necessary or advisable for the proper and advantageous management, investment and distribution of the trust created hereunder, and to make, sign and deliver any instruments or agreements binding this trust.â€Â  
In addition to the powers specified in the trust agreement, the agreement provides the trustee â€œshall have all the powers provided in the statutes.â€Â  Section 62-7-704(c)(19) of the South Carolina Probate Code (Supp. 2004), imparts powers to a trustee, including the power â€œto pay or contest any claim; to settle a claim by or against the trust by compromise, arbitration, or otherwise[.]â€Â  Thus, the trust agreement and the statutory authority give Moran the power to compromise a claim on behalf of the trust.Â  
Finally, the University, as a beneficiary under the trust, does have the ability to influence the courtâ€™s decision whether to approve the compromise agreement.Â  Section 62-1-201(20) of the Probate Code provides the following definition for â€œinterested person:â€Â  

â€œInterested personâ€ includes heirs, devisees, children, spouses, creditors, beneficiaries, and any others having a property right in or claim against a trust estate or the estate of a decedent, ward, or protected person which may be affected by the proceeding.Â  It also includes persons having priority for appointment as personal representative and other fiduciaries representing interested persons.Â  The meaning as it relates to particular persons may vary from time to time and must be determined according to the particular purposes of, and matter involved in, any proceeding.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-201(20) (1987).
Under this statute, we find the University is an interested person.Â  Section 62-3-1102(3) of the Probate Code states interested persons are entitled to receive notification prior to a courtâ€™s decision to approve a compromise agreement.Â  The University did in fact receive such notice in this case.Â  Upon receipt of notification, the University objected to the compromise agreement and was given an opportunity to voice its objection to the probate court prior to the courtâ€™s decision on whether or not to approve the compromise agreement.Â  Section 62-3-1102 of the South Carolina Probate Code, however, does not require interested persons execute the compromise agreement in order for a court to approve the agreement.Â  Thus, the University, as an interested party, is entitled to receive notice of a proposed compromise, but its signature is not required for court approval of the agreement.Â  
CONCLUSION
We hold the Anderson Trust is the beneficiary of Mrs. Andersonâ€™s estate, and Moran, as trustee, is the person required to execute the compromise agreement.Â  Because only the trust, as holder of the beneficial interest, must sign the compromise agreement, the circuit court did not err in concluding the requirements of section 62-3-1102 were met.Â  Section 62-3-1102(3) mandates that an interested person receive notice of a proposed compromise, and allows the interested person to participate in the proceedings, including objecting to any compromise agreement.Â  Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: Primerica Life Insurance Company v. Ingram
description: Finding that there is a genuine issue of material fact whether the applicants made a statement with the intent to defraud the insurer, the court reverses the grant of summary judgment in favor of the insurance company and remands to allow the jury to decide.
text:
Primerica v. Ingram


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Primerica Life Insurance Company, Respondent,
v.
Ray K. Ingram, Sr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4017
Heard June 16, 2005 â€“ Filed July 18, 2005

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Michael M. Jordan, of Sumter, for Appellant.Â  
Robert H. Hood, Mary Agnes Hood Craig, D. Nathan Hughey, and Deborah H. Sheffield, all of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Primerica Insurance Company, Inc. filed this action against Ray K. Ingram, Sr. seeking rescission of a life insurance policy and policy rider.Â  Ingram counterclaimed for breach of contract and bad faith refusal to pay insurance proceeds.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment to Primerica.Â  Ingram appeals.Â  We reverse and remand.Â  
FACTS
Ray Ingram and his wife, Rachel, applied for and procured life insurance on each of their lives:Â  a policy on Ingramâ€™s life in the amount of $223,000, and a policy rider on Rachelâ€™s life providing for a $104,000 death benefit.Â  At the time of the application, Rachel had been diagnosed with and was being treated for cardiomyopathy.Â  Less than two months after the policy and rider were issued, Rachel died from cardiac arrhythmia associated with cardiomyopathy.Â  Ingram made a claim under the policy rider for the death benefit.Â  Primerica denied Ingramâ€™s claim based on the failure to disclose Rachelâ€™s diagnosis and treatment for a heart condition.Â  
Ingram and Rachel met with two agents of Primerica Life Insurance Company to complete the application.Â  One of the agents filled out the application while questioning the Ingrams.Â  The application included the following instruction: 

The following questions must be answered for Primary, and if applicable, Spouse and Child(ren): 
In the past 10 years have you been treated for or had any indication of: 
2A.Â  Chest pain, angina, heart murmur, heart attack, stroke, or other disorder of the heart or blood vessels? 

To the right of the question, the application provided â€œyesâ€ and â€œnoâ€ boxes for the applicant to check under two different columnsâ€”one labeled â€œPrimaryâ€ and the other labeled â€œSpouse and/or Child.â€Â  On the application, the â€œyesâ€ box was checked under both the â€œPrimaryâ€ column and the â€œSpouse and/or Childâ€ column.Â  
The application also requested â€œDetails of Medical Questions 1 through 7.â€Â  Under the details section, the application indicated Ingram suffered from chest pain and had been treated at Tuomey Hospital.Â  In addition, the application indicated Aaron, the Ingramsâ€™ son, was born with a heart murmur.Â  There were no details provided regarding Rachel. 

Another section of the application contained the following questions: 
  
In the past 3 years other than as answered above, have you:Â  
Had any checkup or examination or been a patient in a hospital, clinic or other medial facility? 
Had any electrocardiogram, x-ray or diagnostic test?Â  
Been advised to have any diagnostic test, hospitalization or surgery which has not yet been done?Â  
  

Again, to the right of each question, the application contained â€œyesâ€ and â€œnoâ€ boxes under the headings of Primary and Spouse and/or Child.Â  All three boxes under Primary were checked yes and all three boxes under Spouse and/or Child were checked no.Â  The application also provided a space below for â€œDetails of Medical Questions 8 through 10.â€Â  Information regarding various procedures performed on Ingramâ€™s heart was provided.Â  No information on Rachel was provided.
Ingram does not dispute the existence of his wifeâ€™s heart condition at the time the couple executed the application.Â  Nor does he dispute the absence of this information in the application.Â  Additionally, Ingram admits that if this information had been disclosed, it would have been material to the risk to the insurer.Â  However, Ingram argues he and Rachel disclosed this information to Primericaâ€™s agents, and the agents failed to include it in the application.Â  Thus, he contends he did not intend to defraud Primerica.Â  

Ingram testified in his deposition: 
  
I brought up the heart condition, the micro, whatever the situation is.Â  I still canâ€™t pronounce it.Â  But I think she told them about, also, she had, in the past, [been] diagnosed with a lump in her breast.
* * *
We went so far dealing with the heart micro prolapse, or whatever the name of the thing is, until she got up to went to try - - she went and got her medicine bottle, the pills that she was taking. 
  

In addition, Ingram testified his wife told the agents about her dizziness, the blurring in her eyes, and the heaviness she felt in her chest.Â  Ingram stated his wife also told the agents about her recent doctorsâ€™ appointments and her doctorâ€™s name.Â  Furthermore, Ingram and Rachel signed authorizations to obtain medical records.Â  
The agent who took the information from the Ingrams testified in his deposition that Rachel did not inform him of her heart condition or related symptoms or treatment.Â  However, he recalled Rachel bringing a pill bottle or prescription bottle into the room.Â  
Ingram reviewed the application after the agents filled it in.Â  In his testimony regarding whether he actually read the application prior to signing it, Ingram stated he did not read the application word-for-word.Â  Rather, he â€œlooked at the â€˜yesâ€™ or â€˜noâ€™ answers and kind of like just glanced across everything else and then we signed it.â€Â  In regard to information about his wife on the application, Ingram testified: 

That particular part, I reviewed and when I reviewed, I reviewed the question and when I saw the â€˜yesâ€™ checked where it asked the question on 2A, I think it was, about the chest pains and whatever and the heart murmur and whatnot, when I looked under for spouse and/or children[,] when it [sic] saw it checked â€˜yesâ€™ I didnâ€™t observe the documentation that [the agent] wrote down on that.Â  I was comfortable when I saw the â€˜yesâ€™ checked and that at that moment that we disclosed everything we needed to. 

Primerica brought this action against Ingram seeking to have the policy and rider rescinded.Â  Ingram answered and counterclaimed, alleging breach of contract and bad faith by Primerica.Â  Primerica filed a motion for summary judgment on Ingramâ€™s bad faith claim and on its rescission claim.Â  The trial court, in two separate orders, granted both of Primericaâ€™s motions.Â  Ingram appeals the trial courtâ€™s order awarding summary judgment on the rescission claim. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhen reviewing the grant of summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same standard applied by the trial court pursuant to Rule 56(c), SCRCP.â€Â 
White v. J.M. Brown Amusement Co., 360 S.C. 366, 370, 601 S.E.2d 342, 344 (2004).Â  Pursuant to Rule 56(c), SCRCP, summary judgment is appropriate when no genuine issue of material fact exists entitling the moving party to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Id.Â  In determining whether a genuine issue of material fact exists, the trial court must view all evidence and inferences in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id. at 370-71, 601 S.E.2d at 344. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Ingram argues the trial court
erred in granting Primerica summary judgment on its rescission claim because the
record contains evidence creating a genuine issue of material fact as to whether
he and Rachel made a false statement with the intent to defraud Primerica. 
We agree.

In order to rescind an
insurance policy on the ground of fraudulent misrepresentation, the insurer must
show by clear and convincing evidence:  (1)
the statement was false; (2) the falsity was known to the applicant; (3) the
statement was material to the risk; (4) the
statement was made with the intent to defraud the insurer; and (5) the
insurer relied on the statement when issuing the policy. 
Strickland
v. Prudential Ins. Co. of Am.,
278 S.C.
82, 86-87, 292 S.E.2d 301, 304 (1982).  


    We find a genuine issue exists as to the Ingramsâ€™ intent to defraud Primerica.Â  In Lanham v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of South Carolina, Inc., 349 S.C. 356, 563 S.E.2d 331 (2002), the South Carolina Supreme Court reviewed a trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of an insurer on a claim for rescission.Â  The court in Lanham considered the issue of whether a material question of fact existed as to the insuredâ€™s intent to defraud the insurer.Â  Id.Â  The court determined:Â  â€œViewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Lanham, it cannot be said, as a matter of law, that he made a false statement in his application with the actual intent to deceive.â€Â  Id. at 365, 563 S.E.2d at 335.Â  The court stated that â€œwhether [Lanham] made a false representation with the actual intent to deceive presents a jury question.â€Â  Id.
    Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Ingram, we likewise find a question of fact exists in this case as to whether Ingram and Rachel intended to defraud Primerica.Â  Thus, the trial court erred in granting Primerica summary judgment on its claim for rescission.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial court is
    REVERSED and REMANDED.Â  
     ANDERSON and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: Longshore v. Saber Security Services
description: This case determines that the jury finding of comparative negligence on the part of the plaintiff in one cause of action is not applicable in a separate cause of action tried in the same suit, and reverses an award of punitive damages.
text:
Longshore v. Saber Securities


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Christopher Longshore, Appellant/Respondent,
v.
Saber Security Services, Inc., and Named Individual Marc A. Shafer, Defendants, Of Whom Saber Security Services, Inc., is,
Respondent/Appellant,
and Named Individual Marc A. Shafer is, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Laurens County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4019
Heard February 8, 2005 â€“ Filed July 25, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Karl Bryant Allen, of Greenville, and Max Thomas Hyde, Jr., of Spartanburg, for Appellant-Respondent.
R. Hawthorne Barrett, of Columbia, for Respondent-Appellant. 
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  This case arises from a shooting incident at the Laurens National Guard Armory.Â  While breaking up a fight, Marc A. Shafer, a security guard for Saber Security Services, Inc., shot Christopher Longshore causing serious injuries.Â  Longshore brought actions for negligent use of deadly force, negligent hiring, training, and supervision, and assault and battery.Â  The jury returned an inconsistent or incomplete verdict on the negligent use of deadly force claim, a verdict for Saber and Shafer on the assault and battery action, and a substantial verdict for both actual and punitive damages against Saber on the negligent hiring, training, and supervision cause of action.Â  Saber and Longshore appeal.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTS
The Incident
In December 1996, Longshore attended a party at the National Guard Armory in Laurens County.Â  Saber provided two security guards for this event, one of whom was Shafer.Â  As the party was winding down, Shafer and the other security guard were directing traffic when a fight broke out.Â  A crowd gathered around the scene, and someone pulled out a pistol and fired three shots into the air.Â  After briefly taking cover, the security guards began working their way through the crowd checking on the safety of those leaving the party.Â  The security guards stopped two people and searched for weapons, but found none.Â  They then observed a vehicle containing three or four individuals, two of whom were fighting.Â  They saw an individual, later identified as Derrick Bluford, fire four shots into the crowd wounding two people.Â  
Shafer testified he ran up to the car and ordered the shooter to drop his weapon and get on the ground.Â  After initially balking, the shooter eventually complied.Â  Shafer disarmed him and handed the weapon to the other security guard.Â  
At about that time, Longshore, who is Blufordâ€™s brother, stopped his car about 50 feet away and began walking toward Shafer and Bluford.[1]Â  Shafer testified he saw a passenger in Longshoreâ€™s vehicle pointing a nickel-plated automatic weapon at him over the top of the car.Â  Shafer advanced toward Longshore and ordered Longshore to put his hands in the air.Â  Longshore and several eyewitnesses testified that Longshore put both hands in the air, but Shafer testified that Longshore kept one hand behind his back.Â  Shafer further testified that Longshore kept advancing toward him after he told Longshore to stop or he would shoot.Â  Shafer then shot Longshore in the stomach.Â  
Later that evening, police officers found a chrome-plated automatic weapon in Longshoreâ€™s car.Â  Another witness, Clifford Cook, testified the weapon was registered to him and that he had put the gun in the glove compartment of Longshoreâ€™s car.Â  
Shaferâ€™s Hiring and Training
Saber hired Shafer approximately two weeks before the shooting incident occurred.Â  Shafer applied, was recommended by another employee, and was hired the following day.Â  Saber did not check Shaferâ€™s employment references, age, or high school diploma, as required by company policy.Â  
Because Shafer was already licensed through the State Law Enforcement Division (SLED) as an armed security guard, Saber did not train Shafer for the position.Â  Saber took Shaferâ€™s fingerprints and discussed the companyâ€™s weapons policy with him.Â  Shafer, however, failed to complete the weapons policy form in violation of company policy.Â  
Shafer was also required to have SLED transfer his license from his former employer to Saber.Â  It is undisputed that Shafer had not yet received his transferred license on the date the shooting occurred.Â  Pursuant to state law at that time, security guards could work but could not carry a weapon until receipt of a license.Â  
The Verdicts
The first cause of action, negligence, was submitted to the jury on the direct negligence of Shafer and vicarious negligence of Saber, on the theory that Shafer was Saberâ€™s agent.Â  The jury found both defendants negligent and that their negligence proximately caused Longshoreâ€™s injuries.Â  The jury additionally found, however, that Longshore was also negligent and that his negligence proximately caused his injuries.Â  Fault was allocated 50% to the defendants and 50% to Longshore.Â  The jury then awarded zero damages.Â
